TLDR: Massively faithful to Warhammer Fantasy Battles, must buy for fans, Magic and heroes are awesome, base game is worth it alone.   A fun game which doesn't require you to have any previous knowledge of the Warhammer series at all, though of course it certainly helps enhance the experience if you do.  The campaign-wise I've found it to be the most challenging and punishing of recent total war games (at least before you start snowballing.)   Through Lords and Heroes we now have very powerful avatars who are able to enhance your troops and debuff your enemies all while being absolute monsters of war in their own right.   The magic system adds a new layer to battles, although it's been toned down from release you will still find that proper use of your spells can make a massive impact on your battle performance.  I can see many people are upset about DLC pricing and the ammount of it to expect for this game. Let me just tell you that you need none of it, they will continue adding free content to the game and if you do exhaust the four main factions as well as the future ones they will be adding for ~FREE~ (Bretonnia next at time of writing) then you can enhance your experience with DLC. It's up to you, as it stands the base game is definitely worth the money.

Alright so I've put allot of hours into this game before I finally posted a review, in order to be fair and balanced about it. Each race has their own unique feel to the game, different tatics for both battle and campaign. They've done very well at balancing out the game with their units. You play the Empire or you play the Orcs, your going to have a totally different gaming play style - it's very cool what they did here and gives replayability which was really lacking in their other Total War games.   Is it perfect? NO.... But the table top game went through EIGHT versions (updates) in the 25+ years it was out to iron out gameplay. And it still wasn't perfect either. So people need to take a serious chill pill on their reviews. Since 1990 I've played Warhammer Fantasy and the tabletop game is better now. So balancing gameplay takes time to well balance.  I have played almost all the races in the table top game and only a few units are missing from this game. CA promises to add others for free with their updates. Newest being the Blood Knights - yes tough dudes.  --- Battles are too fast I hear people cry out in other reviews. Well they are fast in the table top too - by the second round of combat on average, someone is running usually - and unlike the game here, if you break and run in the table top and are caught - you entire unit is killed. And yes if you do run in the table top and not get caught, you do usually rally to fight some more, just like the game here does.  --- Spells aren't susposed to be over-powered. They used to be in Warhammer's early days, and trust me not fun - one spell killing half your army. The Purple Sun spell used to kill whole units. AND if they did it 100% same as table top, the defender would have a chance to stop or dispel your spell castings - so be glad they didn't do that. Only miscasting now seem to be if your wizard takes damage. And they've done well to limit total amount of castings with their spell pool.  --- Magic items in TW Warhammer are pretty cool - they did a great job porting/coverting them over. There are a ton to choose from, many more they can add.  --- Then you got people complaining about the whole chaos invasion thing. Well they are taking it from the End Times book series line Games Workshop did last. YES when Chaos invaded it was 'holy crap' we are all going to die unless we band together. And yes in the book series, the Vampires allied with the Empire. In the book series, Chaos won - just to tell you how powerful their invasion was. Aldorf destroyed in the book series.  --- Yes the campaign stuff is susposed to be simple - this isn't Empire or Rome or Attila Total War (I own almost all TW titles except Attila), this is Warhammer. And Warhammer is about battles. Can they impove it? Sure - but personally I like it the way it is. You want more, then play another Total War game - go crazy with mico management in that game.  --- Is this game easy? Perhaps to some I am sure - but honestly it is NOT. I've not totally lost, but I've gotten my butt stomped plenty of times. One senario: I was playing The Empire, nine armies I got - fighting beginning Chaos invasion (Norse only) and winning sizeable. I moved three armies down to finally deal with the Vampire Counts and knock them out - then all of a sudden I got five maxed Orc armies with a Waaagh coming through Dead Pass. What do you think happened? Yep just like that, my power went 'poof' - I lost cities, armies, generals until I could bring my northern forces down. Once I lost cities, I lost income, then I lost trade - my sizeable 10k saved gold reserves gone. Takes many, many turns to build up a city/town in this game - so yes the Orcs messed me up good.  What I failed to do was help stop the Orc tide. So because I didn't help with the Orcs, they grew like the plague - almost all the Dwarves dead. And beat the snot out of me. Now in my weaken state, I got to stop the Orcs, the Vampires AND Chaos. I don't give myself good odds I win this one.  Next senario: I'm playing the Vampire Counts - kicking butt, taking names - slowly winning against The Empire, the next thing I know almost everyone declares war on me. My four Armies overwelmed by the attacks of practically everyone. You being undead means no one really likes you to begin win, trading for income almost non-exsistant. So your economy is going to be much smaller than playing the Empire or Dwarfs. So less money = less armies. I quit this game rather than face the crushing defeat I saw coming (heh).  So YES if you don't have tactics - long term tactics while playing this game, or you can get whomped in a hurry. You got to plan. To be honest, I don't remember having this happen in any other Total War game. Though I haven't beaten them all.  --- People complain that the game goes to fast, well try hiking out your army to your characters quest points instead of teleporting, that will make the game VERY interesting and longer right there. Now what do you do when your attacked and your main guy, your toughest general is ten or more turns away to help?  This game is FUN and ENJOYABLE and I'm having a blast playing it. I am happy CA did this - so much to do in this game. Allot of expansion packs to do, many more races - bigger campaign map will HAVE to happen.  So just have patience people and quit being a bunch of cry babies. You can get mods for the game if you want to fix stuff, but personally I don't have any crazy ones. Better camera, new loading screens, etc..   Thanks for reading!! I hope it helps you.

Probably the best Total War game I've played. Games Workshop's Warhammer Fantasy sertting is a great fit for Total War. Who knew?  Total War: Warhammer plays out like the other entries in the series with a strategic map where you manage finances, move armies, and promote generals; and a tactical map where you fight individual battles. There are agents for all your cloak & dagger stuff, and buildings to help develop your provinces. That's about the extent of the similarities.  Warhammer gives four playable factions (five if you have access to Chaos) that are quite different from each other. The unit rosters aren't necessarily the same. Some armies (Vampire Counts in particular) have no ranged units whatsoever, while others (dwarfs) have nothing resembling cavalry. This gives a distinctly different flavor than prior games where everyone had infantry and cavalry and archers, it's just that some of them had longer spears or pointier hats or bigger shields. The factions also have different mechanics (like the Greenskin fightiness) to make them all unique. Some factions can't colonize or occupy the territories of others, though you can still invade, sack, loot, and burn their settlements to the ground. This makes for a lot of replayability.  Heroes and Lords are much more awesome in this game compared to previous ones. With the magic available in a high fantasy setting a single hero can wipe out hundreds of infantrymen by himself. That's the sort of thing prior games and their silly devotion to 'realism' would never allow. Just like heroes in other fantasy settings, Total War: Warhammer heroes can go on spiffy quests for their own phat lootz.  Both the campaign and the tactical AI are not terrible. It's hard to make a decent AI for a game with as many variables as this, but your opponents put up a good fight. If that's too lame you can always play multiplayer. There are skirmish battles available, but there's also a mod already out that let's you fight through the campaign co-op.  Lastly there are much fewer bugs than I'd expect from a Total War game. I love me some Shogun 2, but that game did kind of crash a lot. I think Warhammer crashed for me twice so far.  All in all the Creative Assembly people have outdone themselves for this game.

Increadibly weary of my once favourite franchise after Rome 2, some of Atilla's few but noticable issues, the business practises of CA (or the forced money-making schemes forced on them by Sega, more accurately) and the general lack of any real significant progress in game-design since Shogun 2, I deliberately delayed buying this game.  Approaching it with a relatively open mind, yet with the experience of playing every Total War since the first Rome, I can safely recommend this game to both Total War fans, no matter how disgruntled, and Warhammer Fantasy fans alike.  There are, in the base game, four playable faction, each a particular race. This may sound far too few, but each race is so unique in both aesthetic, management and style that I can completely understand the modest launch booster. In fact, I realised playing this game just how stale the previous TW entries have been, even ones I was very fond off. The differences between playing as Hojo and Takeda, or the Wester Roman Empire and the Picts, seem almost nonexistent compared, for example, playing the Vampire Counts and Dwarfs. The VCs field meatshield expendable zombies in the early game that can be allowed to decimate, only to raise more after each battle with their unique faction ability (the size and scope of the battle affects how many units and the types) and slowly spreading 'Vampiric Corruption' into neighbouring Provinces before a midgame explosion where, with an economy and unit recruitment system that sees a weak early game but powerful midgame, you take one human province after enough, the ground and sky growing dark and corrupted across more and more of the surrounding map, and you FEEL like some cancerous force of undeath spreading uncontrollably. No more cheap zombie and skeletons units; now you have monstrous winged undead beasts able to challenge 200 men singlehandidly and your Black Knights slaughtering their back lines en masse.  Then, the Dwarfs, who force you to turtle in their mountain regions and build your defenses against the constant hordes of Greenskins and their WAAAAGHs (basically free full army stacks), maybe taking one or few provinces until finally your economy has hit a strong enough point to give you access to devastating cannons, flamethrower and bomb dropping 'Gyrocopters' to reclaim the Southenlands from the Orks and Goblins who've you've been fending off since the start.  But then Chaos, the 'final boss' factions appears, and you discover that the North barely exists anymore; a half barren wasteland, destroyed settlement hosting Chaos Towers that spread the taint further towards your own lands. As previous enemies begin to parly due to a new affinity which is essentially a 'we don't want to see the world destroyed' common interest, you march your troops into lands you never even imagined treading on in a heroic effort to stop Chaos before the Horde's of Archeon have swelled too large.  Every new feature, for the most part, is a change for the better. A better game, a different game. Worried about how Factions can only take settlements belonging to their own or 'cousin' faction (dwarf/orks, human/VC)? Well, now you have the added game feature of a far more tactiful campaign of actually having to truly plan your expansion on a level that Atilla and Shogun 2 often ended as simply 'there's no REAL reason why i shouldn't just take this province x100'. Confederations, which is the only feature I'm still not certain how I feel about, does at least also add more addition fun gameplay:  'Ok, I can't really declare war on Zhufbar to my North, as their currently the only force preventing a full Undead outbreak due to their threat they pose to the Vampire capital. But perhaps, if I send an army to help harrase the forces of the Vampire Counts and also unite with them against the Beastmen Tribe, while also expanding my power until I finally eclipse their's, my relationship with them may get to the point where they're willing to fulling join with my empire.'  In-regars to the Chaos Warriors DLC; hmm. It IS a reasonable price, all things considered, but it is dubious that you have to pay additional money to play as a faction that already exists in the game, let alone ACTS as the final boss. However, their unique style of play, although essentially the system used for the Huns in Atilla (which existed in the base game), is worth £5.   Not sure where I stand on the issue of that particular DLC, or its quality. But I can say safely that the modular launches apparently planned that will (apparently, again) add a new map (that can be connected and played with the base map) hosting currently missing factions will be something I am happy about the prospect of buying.  I'm also suprised by how unfazed I was playing the vanilla game, compared to Rome 2. While there are plenty of mods that really do enhance the game to an amazing extent (the modding community of this game deserves HUGE credit), there's nothing added that I feel is an essential that the base game previously lacked. The only manner in which the mods, to me, reveal shortcomings in the basegame are firstly inregards to balancing (Radious etc) which help give the game a far more strategic edge (and an AI that isn't too stupid or overpowered) and ones that give the Chaos faction more playability.  Overrall, I am very happy with this game, and even more happy about the potential future of TW it teases. Colorful, immersive and increadibly enjoyable, be your interest be in the turn based campaign or the real time battles, I feel like this game is a true return to form, taking all the successful ideas in Atilla and Rome 2 (mostly the former, tho) while remedying the weak points of both.  The vanilla game, for me, is a solid 8/10. Remember; that's without adding to the score the utterly fantastic modding community, driven now not only by fanatical fans of TW but also lovers of the Warhammer tabletop game.  Would I buy full price? Yes. Would I press a friend to buy it on 25% off sale? Yes. Would I buy the DLC full price? Yes. Would I press a friend to buy the DLC on 25% off sale? No, depending on their preferences inregards to the gameplay addition each module offers.

Let me state up front that I have a love-hate relationship with the Total War franchise. I love Medieval 2 Total War and Rome Total War, I find them to be two of the most enjoyable games ever designed. However, Empire and the other more recent entries in the series just weren't that interesting to me. I found that they did not have enough variety, not only in simple aesthetic but in strategic and tactical options from nation to nation. Even Shogun 2 was a let down for me.   But this game, oh boy. This game changes all of that. And that is not just because I am a massive Warhammer enthusiast -- I know that's hard to believe but fortunately I have had some formal education in game design, and when I ignore the Warhammer parts of the game and think about the game mechanics themselves it's still plain to see that this entry stands head and shoulders above most others in the franchise.  That is not to say it is entirely without flaws, but one of the most important things is that this game shipped with far fewer flaws than other recent entries in the Total War series, both from technical and design perspectives. The one consistent feeling I get when I play Total Warhammer (as I call it for short), is that Creative Assembly really learned. And I mean really, really learned and applied all of their knowledge, examined and corrected almost all of their mistakes and combined all of the game mechanics they've tried throughout the franchise that were successful. It was quite heartwarming, actually, for you see I am fairly cynical -- I don't expect developers to learn from their mistakes usually. At least, not the ones that matter. But CA did that, and they went further beyond by applying all the best mechanics from the franchise in the best ways possible.  Let me start by talking about the factions. Each of the factions play completely differently. The Empire play as you would expect -- the traditional Total War experience. Occupying, sacking, or razing towns, managing public order, and additionally you can appoint your characters to Offices which give you global bonuses. Dwarves are similar, yet they're still more different from the Empire than any faction is from any other in any previous Total War game. It only gets more divergent from there.  I don't want to exhaustively go over every single faction's details, but I can give a basic example. Warriors of Chaos, for instance, can't take settlements -- they can only maintain a glorious host and bring glory to the Dark Gods by looting, maiming, killing and burning everything in their path. From what I understand, this 'Horde' mechanic was lifted from Total War Attila, and it fits the theme and army makeup of Chaos extremely well.   The Heroes and Lords definitely deserve a mention, since they're one of the biggest changes to the game. Heroes are very powerful single characters that can take on multiple melee units by themselves. They also serve as your agents on the campaign strategy map. Your generals are also Lords, which behave much like Heroes on the battlefield. Both Heroes and Lords can level up and acquire equipment (wargear); the primary difference is their purpose on the campaign strategy map. This was a big focal point for many fans of the franchise, because if done poorly, it could easily ruin the game. I'm here to tell you that there's nothing to worry about; they're done quite well. Some Legendary Lords, who are faction leaders that can't die permanently, are very powerful -- but then, they're supposed to be, and they frequently have awful drawbacks. Grimgor Ironhide, for instance, is an extremely powerful melee combatant that can take on several melee units at once, but he is a very large target -- this actually matters because it gives your archers a clearer shot over their own men's heads -- and he is not very fast. The wargear either gives a passive bonus or an active ability that can be used in-game. Sometimes it's quite significant. The ruby ring of ruin allows the wearer to cast fireball once every battle. The counter strategy for these characters depends on the individual character you're fighting. Wizards can be killed in simple melee, for instance.  As far as aesthetics, the art is pretty damn good. Vibrant colors adorn every army, and there's a variety of environments to fight on as well. Additionally, certain... environmental changes may occur during the course of your campaign. Performance is actually, pretty decent, despite what one usually expects from Total War games. And the graphics are still as good as they're known for being from the most recent entries. But really what they knocked out of the park is the game's music. There is a great variety of music depending on which faction is losing or winning a battle, which faction you're panned over on the campaign map, etc. And the tracks are absolutely excellent. Really, I can't emphasize enough that these are some of the best music tracks in video games. The voice work is kinda corny -- American accented Empire, really? -- but, as usual, Greenskins are absolutely flawless, as they've been since the original Dawn of War.  In fact, speaking of Dawn of War, I believe Dawn of War 1 was in many ways the best adaptation of Warhammer 40,000 to a computer game. Total Warhammer is like that, but for Warhammer Fantasy. And it seems like Creative Assembly means to take it all the way, adding every faction in via expansions, just like Relic did with Dawn of War. It's a great game now and it seems like it's only going to get better.

This is my first total war game that i had any experience so bare in mind that this review comes from a first time  total war fan.And i can say that this game is a whole lot of fun.  First of all,the fantasy setting of the game is what really drew me into this game especially the warhammer universe.This makes the game's factions unique in their own ways and preventing them from becoming stale unlike the other historical factions from other total wars.  Now lets talk gameplay.As said before this game's factions are all unique and are not just different factions with different units with barely any change in gameplay.But total war:warhammer really nailed it with the diversity among these factions.An example of thhis diverseness can be seen by each factions interraction during the campaign.The dwarves might be defensive and confederate whith other dwarves,the greenskins meanwhile are an offensive faction which possess turmoil among other greenskin tribes.  Continuing in gameplay now lets look at the battles,one of the main functions that make total war the way it is.The battles in this game can reach varrying levels of epicness.The massive scale of battles among this game make for a great experience.A fact that can attribute to this is the hit detection among the units.I can say that hit detection is good but can certainly improve.Formations among units also break too easily making some fights a big free-for-all.But aside from these minor complaints battles in this game are won through STRATEGY and not just numbers.Tactical placement of units and micromanagement can hugely swing the tide of battle.  A subject that i would like to commend the game for is the large variety and design between units,This can be attributed to the fact that this toal war is in a fantasy setting letting the developer get more freedom in design.  My minor complaints are that shock cavalry at least in easy-normal modes are slightly op because they can easily penetrate the backline and absolutely decimate infrantry.And the diplomacy system in the game.The diplomacy system just feels unrealistic because you are just waiting to overpower other factions/tribes so that they would agree to your terms,therefore just making it kind of like a power check instead of actual diplomacy.Although it is handy during campaign,i think it could have been more developed to the point that you could win with diplomacy alone like some other strategy games do.  Conclusion: Overall,this game is a ton of blast to play and often inspires the last-turn mentality that you will experience over and over again.With tons of replayability between the different factions,amazing large scale battles,units that are imaginations gone wild,and only a few minor complaints, i can say that Total war:Warhammer is a great game that should be tried by people who are looking for epic battles between armies,the thrill of managing an empire via campaign map,and people who are hesitant to play a total war game just like i was before i played this game

I recommend this game for newcomers to the series (Total War, that is) or Warhammer fans looking for an RTS. If you're a Total War fan and expect a new, complex strategy game with turn-based and tactical elements, then go somewhere else. Why?   All nuances of balancing buildings in settlements is entirely gone. You have a very limited scope of buildings you can manage. Managing populations has never been easier since there are essentially only one public order building, instead of multiple structures that address multiple problems. The economics have been streamlined down to essentially spamming the same building in every region unless you get a unique option and upgraded it to hell.  Managing things like food surplus, etc, is entirely gone. Essentially what we have is Total War stripped to it's bare bones.  Other problems I have are the lack of diversity in maps. Battles play out much the same: flat, uninspired landscapes. The enemy AI will either charge dumbly at you or never engage you at all. There's very little complexity for the AI which is unfortunate because the AI is mostly what you will be facing unless you opt out of single player entirely.  It's 2016 and CA can't create a competent AI. Harder difficulties equal AI that cheats, and even on normal the AI is capable of moving a great distance, sacking a city, then moving again when the player armies hvae very limited movement ranges and things such as rivers actually form obstacles for you, and only you. Instead of actually trying to flank your troops with cavalry or break specific units, the AI will march towards you in a straight line on every difficulty, attack you head on (if it opts to attack at all) and the difficulty scale merely means the AI will have armour, weapon, and morale boosts that actually make winning battles absurdly difficult when the AIs' approach is identical.   In previous Total War games you could cut an enemy army off at a river and bottle neck them on a bridge or Ford. Well, that features gone entirely from this game. Your armies placement on the actual campaign map has virtually no relevance to what sort of battlefield you will be on beyond a tileset with a new colour scheme. Fighting in the north? Here's some snow. A lot of the features that added depth to previous installments in the series are entirely gone, and this is most definitely one of them. The obstacles on the world map are obstacles solely for the Human players - AI will march further, be able to ignore the presence of most land barriers such as rivers entirely while your armies movement is slowed by least a turn. This means you'll be playing tag with AI armies such as Orks who do not settle, hoping they will decide to attack you because catching them by other means is almost impossible.  The Old World, for sure, is awfully full of slight slopes. Advertising of 'fantastical' environments that CA promised are absent in virtually almost every regard as there are no real exotic looking areas beyond the Underways (which you will spend virtually 0 time in)./  Auto-resolve is mostly the way to go. There are few instances in this game where you need to fight. Most of the time your army will be capable of easily annhilating targets.  Many of the Legendary Lords are, well, impractical to use vs their melee counterparts. I would love to play as Balthazar Gelt, but compared to Karl Franz he's trash in every way and virtually identical to any wizard hero I can recruit. Using some of these additional legendary lords feels like handicapping yourself until you can recruit their more powerful counterparts, and there's nothing unique to set them apart from the standard recruitable wizards.  Attrition is broken in some areas of the game. In the Badlands, enjoy trying to invade and fight the Ork scourge as the humans. Your armies will die within a few turns of marching unless you constantly set up camps and wait 3-4 turns to replenish a handful of men to continue your conquest. The same is true in the North or vs the Vampires. The AI is totally unaffected by any sort of attrition though, it seems, so any sort of planning on the campaign map is rendered pointless.  Diplomacy is entirely unnecessary. Agents also serve no real useful functions anymore. In previous titles, the use of Agents (now heroes) was necessary to win on the harder difficulties. In Shogun 2, a well-placed Ninja or two could save you from absolute disaster. In this game, well.. They're irrelevant. Your auto-resolve armies are nigh indestructible. As long as the RNG of the game doesn't make every faction you encounter declare war on you (I've had some of the starting factions declare war on me for no discernable reason immediately. In other games I perform the same actions and they leave me alone entirely). Not that diplomacy works at all in higher difficulties anyway until the Chaos invasion comes along about 50 turns in and virtually wipes out eveeryone you're facing. This makes playing as the Beastmen and Orkz laughably easy because most of your work is done for you by the time you've really started to gain momentum. The rest of the game turns into a lengthy mop up operation with no challenge what so ever.   Would I recommend it? Yeah, I guess I would. It has some problems, but at 172 hours and more to come when the game has more factions for me to enjoy, I've definitely got my moneys worth. As a fan of previous Total War games though the removal of all the complexity is really disappointing.Battling AI opponents is dull, Beyond being an achievement ♥♥♥♥♥ there's really no extra challenge to be had in the harder difficulties beyond AI that ups the amount it cheats by than making any semi-intelligent decision beyond marching directly at you or standing on a hill until you come to it.   Desyncs still seem to be a problem in co-op campaigns (I have done more than 10 co-op campaigns). Trying new factions if you're trying to get achievements in the co-op campaigns is also pointless because winning will not grant you a completion achievement for that faction unlike any previous Total War.   The online scene from what I have experienced is mostly just noobs who I assume don't know how counters work spamming giants/pegasi or other monstrous units who then ragequit and ♥♥♥♥♥ at you when a single unit dedicated to killing those types of enemies specifically is single-handedly responsible for ruining their entire strategy.

Adding a faction to the game for 15-20$ and people freak out is absurd to me. This game is incomplete for certain, but with what is there I have already had so much fun. I personally have not purchased any DLC because I am frugal, but I don't think what they are asking for it is unreasonable. Total War: WARHAMMER is by far the most entertaining Total War installment I have played since Medieval II. Here's a nifty list of all the Pros and Cons I have with this Title. Keep in mind I am NOT familiar with WARHAMMER lore so this is in regards to Total War aspects, not WARHAMMER.  PROS: -AI are no longer dumber than a sack of rocks. -You're gonna get flanked and your gonna have a bad time. -Legendary is actually really freaking hard for once. -No playthrough is ever the same (I have beaten the game as the Empire twice on Legendary and Dwarfs once on Legendary and they were completely different each time.) -Battles don't take close to an hour anymore like Legendary Attila did. -The ability to only occupy Vampire or Human lands or Dawi and Ork territory makes it interestingly difficult. -Each races units and battlestyles are very different and fighting the Vampire Counts is a whole different animal than fighting the Dwarfs. -Legendary Lord level system is useful and not garbage like Attila. -Followers are useful and Banners give you cool stuff like Greatswords with flaming weapons.  -The gear from quests make an enormous difference in battle -The Underway is either amazing or will make you cry when a Greenskinz army pops up randomly out of the mountains. -The amazing array of skills and attributes to units is amazing. (Trolls Regenerate, Poison attacks, Flame attacks, Flying Bats ambushing you from behind with their 9999999 speed rating, and so many more.) -Chaos corruption and Vampiric corruption make both of those factions gameplay all the more fun and challenging. (Equivalent to the religions in past TW games except they buff and debuff as well as cause issues with public order) -Agents can now fight along with your lord and armies. They can support and cast magics or they can bullrush into the thick of it and slaughter entire elite units alone giving your Damage Dealers a break to choose other targets. -Pathfinding isn't gonna make you want to punch your screen anymore. -Though the unit selection is lacking for my liking, the races are all equal in power. There is no 'Superior' race at the end game. -You will lose battles more than ever before.  CONS: -What the literal ^%@# did CA do to sieges? -Agents will kill you more than enemy armies. -Success chance of agents based on their level makes late game agents almost useless. -'Unique' building chaings for the most part don't do anything all the special. -Chaos is stupid hard due to the awful replinishment rates they are stuck with. -Nobody uses combat magic because you can do more damage with the magic buffs and debuffs. -Combat magic is almost useless. -If you don't have a unit capable of running down ranged cavalry, well RIP you, enjoy running them into a corner and wasting 20 minutes of your time cornering them just to have them route before you kill them. -Autoresolving is a guarenteed win. (I try not to AR at all as it takes all the fun out of the game) -The terrain in the battles almost always seems to be one-sided. (You're army spawns in ditch, they get the highground with a 200m killzone for their artillery or vice versa. -Last but not least. What the (*&^ did CA do to the sieges?   TL;DR: Game is great and different. Not at all shallow if you play on legendary. You are gonna lose more than ever due to smart AI. CA f***ed up sieges hardcore and they suck now. Good luck, have fun.

Is this a good game? Yes. Is it the best Total War? No. Can it be? Yes, maybe, in time.   What makes it good:   - The graphics, soundtrack, voice work and overall design of the main factions (look, rosters...) are all very good.  - The battles are fun, the new elements like monsters and magic, as well as quests, work well.  - Agents are fun to use and level up, and feel neither too powerful nor too weak (although wizards may not be entirely cost effective).  - Due to the setting of the End Times, there is a certain urgency to your early game expansion, as you know Chaos is coming, which is a great early game motivator to play agressively. However, Chaos and the End Times setting also has a major downside (more on this later). - You can now have as many armies as you want, in theory, but your upkeep goes up by a certain percentage with each new army you get. This is definitely an improvement over the previous system of a fixed maximum number of armies imo.  What holds it back: it lacks depth, and immersion.   - The devs have been talking about how rich the Warhammer lore is and how they're building (and therefore selling) the world of Warhammer piece by piece. Well, I buy this, but then I also want to see this. I want to learn about the lore, through the game. Apart from the main factions, the world and its factions aren't very developed, that is to say, 90 percent are carbon copies of the main factions. This makes exploring (read: conquering) new regions and meeting new peoples less exciting than it should be.  - The main factions' 'feel', look and rosters are unique enough to set them apart, however, their building roster is pretty much the same. So while they have a few unique features each, they're not as unique as they're made out to be. - The Chaos invasion offers the ability to have some good battles, but overall really isn't that difficult to deal with (the Huns in Attila feel like a far greater threat).  - Siege battles really just come down to 'attack this long, usually straight wall'. You basically have the choice between rushing the walls and hiding in the corner, away from the towers, while you whittle down the defenders with magic or artillery, or create a hole in the wall with your artillery / stronger units. Rushing outside with cavalry to harass the attackers is hardly an option due to the limited size of the battlefields. This takes away a lot of the epic feel large siege battles are supposed to have.  - There are no naval battles. To give you an idea, we've had naval battles in every Total War since Empire.  - There are no settlement battles, unless the settlement has walls. I like to see the village I'm trying to defend, guys. To give you an idea, we've had settlement battles since... pretty much forever.  - The autoresolver is still broken - massing weak units and autoresolving is still the way to go. The latest patch may have addressed this, but I'm not sure yet.  - One major issue is that reinforcements show up in the wrong place a lot of the time. This is particularly irritating when you're fighting Chaos, which usually keeps its stacks close together. You'll find yourself autoresolving those fights, because having your armies arrive divided and having to micro-manage so many different fronts all at once just isn't an efficient way to go about it.  - I'm no Warhammer expert, but as far as I know, the canonical ending isn't that you win and defeat Chaos... which means there's nothing in the lore for you once you've defeated Chaos. No world events, no nothing. Once Chaos is defeated, the game becomes (even more) quiet. At this point there usually also won't be anyone who's still strong enough to pose any sort of threat. This takes away the immersion once Chaos is beaten, and offers little incentive to play on to achieve long campaign victories.  - Victory objectives can get kinda silly: I had to destroy the Empire on my Greenskins campaign, and spent the last 20 turns chasing an 'army' consisting of a starving captain, a warrior priest and a battle wizard across Brettonia and then the sea. Some empire.  - The lack of depth isn't helped by the fact Chaos has essentially been cut from the game as a playable faction. - The AI does not build its elite units, likely because it does not know how to build up its settlements to get them. In the three playthroughs I've done, I haven't encountered one Arachnarok, Steam Tank, Terrorgheist or Giant aside from the quest battles or armies that spawned automatically. - The small number of factions, and the relatively short time it takes to complete the campaign, means you'll probably be 'done' with this game faster than any other Total War.  What does it need to be great (these aren't things that are necessarily 'wrong' with the game, just small things that could really make the difference between a good game and a great game. You know, attention to detail.):  - 'Minor' factions like for instance Brettonia and Kislev need to be made more unique, and playable. Brettonia is on its way to getting there, but needs a bigger roster. Kislev needs the Ice Queen, the Kossars, Winged cavalry etc. - all the things that make them feel unique. Not just to offer you more factions to play as, but also to give you greater variety in the enemies you need to fight. I'd be much more interested in the Chaos DLC if I knew I wasn't going to be fighting carbon copies of the Empire nearly all the time. - Minor human factions should have at least one unique unit which you, as the Empire, would be able to get after assimilating them - this would make uniting the provinces feel so much more rewarding. - Victory cinematics. Come on guys, show us you put some extra effort in!  - More legendary lords per faction to choose from - even if you remain limited to 2 per playthrough, this could really help the replay value of the individual campaigns. - More different character portraits, especially for the Empire. Legendary lords are nice and all, but you'd feel more connected to your other generals and heroes if they aren't the same bearded guy every time, right?   All in all I think this game is worth buying, but in its current state, due to the lack of content, I wouldn't buy it at full price.

Total War: Warhammer is the lastest, and most unique title in the Total War franchise. CA tries to gradually bring the now unsupported setting of Warhammer Fantasy into a video game form. Many eyes are upon them, both from fans of their own franchise, as well as those who were into the Warhammer Fantasy hobby or setting. This is no easy task -- the franchise existed since 1983, and went through a total of 8 editions, each brings with it retconns and introduce new units and lore. For CA to reflect both the lore and please the fans is a constant struggle for balance.  And I dare say they did quite well; unlike Warhammer: Battle March, the base game of Total War: Warhammer already features more playable units and as usual the grand campaign as is the tradition of Total War games. The game stayed close to the lore enough to not draw the ire of all but the most hardline Warhammer fans, and remaines mechanically interesting.  It is unfortunately not as complex as many of the franchise older titles in terms of Empire building; instead CA opt to focus more on the battle and perfromance aspects. The game had a much better launch then Rome 2 and runs smoother than Attila. The much more different factions encourages the players to switch to different tactics more drastically than before.  So while the game is lacking in some aspects, it's still one of the better Total War games in the franchise. If you want to try out something different from the franchise, you should definitely consider picking this one up.

After playing Total War for 9 years I have come up with an insanely satisfying way of enjoying the games: Preorder and redeem the bonuses (first DLC), then wait one year for it to be fixed and the DLCs to go on sale before reinstalling and actually playing it. Did it with Rome 2 and this one as well (optimisation issues).  Okay, honestly, I think the game we got on release was worth its value and all the DLC cribbing is just toxic. I myself haven't bought a single DLC yet and will wait for a sale before doing so. The DLCs just add more to an already complete world. I mean think about it: I'm a slow player, but I've already played quite a bit of all four launch factions while completing the campaign of only one - and I already have 111 hours of game time. How many games give you that for full price? I think that if I really played fast and only completed the short campaigns, I'd've finished all four campaigns in 100 hours.  Now about the game:  The Total War formula has become shallow. This is both good and bad. For me, it was heartbreaking as the complexity of the previous installments (especially Attila) was something I absolutely loved. It added challenge and depth to the gameplay beyond the churning out of armies for war. TW:W feels more like a 4X game than a true Total War game - which is fine if, like me, you enjoy RTS as well. The streamlining of the franchise honestly felt like a big 'Eff You' to the older generation of fans.  On the other hand, it has made the game accessible and easy. Also, considering how ridiculous some of the aspects and lore of the Warhammer Fantasy world are, I think it's fair if the game doesn't take itself too seriously either. Think about it, the equivalent of a Doom Diver Catapult in a historical game - does splattering people on walls actually damage them?  Another advantage of that is the avoidance of malfunctioning AI that doesn't really know how to use all the tools at its disposal. Jesus, the diplomacy screen has been basically useless in a lot of Total War games before this and a lot of people are relieved at the exclusion of faction politics - which makes sense considering that this game centres around its 'faction leaders' who are basically either longlived or immortal or their death will make their faction redundant (like Karl Franz). I myself have spent too much time staring at my family tree and making appointments and solving dilemmas to not feel quite headless in this game.  Total War is a unique franchise that combines Turn Based Strategy with Real Time battles - which is why it was perfect for Warhammer. The fantasy setting is brilliant and fun and really glorious and enjoyable (knocking a chaos giant on his ♥♥♥ with a cannon is always hilarious).  So, my final verdict would be this: Buy it if you want a fun, not too serious, funny, fantasy themed, graphically beautiful (but not specs intensive) but shallow, easy and sometimes glitchy game, then this is for you. It's more RTS rather than Grand Strategy, but it's well executed.  If you're new to the franchise - welcome. This is a brilliant game that is quite rewarding with long term effects of decisions and quite a bit more strategy than your usual RTS (I mean the army you just attack-moved to the opposite side of the map in the last battle should be available in the next one right? Instead you start with a town center and a bunch of vilagers). This is a great game to start with and I hope it will introduce you to the rest of the franchise.  But if you're a regualr Total War player, remember that they've removed the following: (relevant) Faction Politics, negative effects from buildings, strategic sieges and siege escalation (ugh, they've added pocket ladders), city maps (every city in the Old World is basically Helm's Deep), minor settlement battles, cavalry and infantry formations and stances, naval battles (which fits with the lore), individual combat animations (even for the lords and heroes), building trees (each type of building chain only progresses in one order) all depth and strategy from the campaign or battles, seasons and weather (no rain, snow, night or fog) and large maps (seriously... the battle maps are ♥♥♥♥ing tiny!) among other things. The campaign map is basically just a tabletop to move your armies around and give them reasons to fight and add modifiers to the battle terrain. What they have added though is heroes in battles (I want agents to work like this, albeit with a bodyguard, in every Total War from now), hero customisation, flying units (they're pretty cool, but bring in another host of problems - can't hide, can't take off and land at will, can't dismount), a variety of really interesting creatures that are fun to play and watch, magic (which is actually quite usefull).  Yeah, consider all that while buying, I'd rate this game 7/10  Hopefully, the next TW will either be the historical one they promised (with Attila like complexity) or if it is a Warhammer game, then it brings back some of the layers from the franchise.

Made a goblin diver commit suicide by shooting him into a steam tank. 10/10, would shoot suicide goblins again.  But seriously... as an avid Total War gamer and Warhammer player I can say this:  This IS the WARHAMMER FANTASY game you are looking for.  This IS the TOTAL WAR game you are looking for, if you didn't like the others in the series.  This IS NOT the TOTAL WAR game you are looking for, if you enjoyed titles such as Atila and Empire.  The game is great in all aspects. It is an ideal version of warhammer fantasy, beating previous attempts to capture the games charm, such as mark of chaos. Its a streamlined and simplified version of the usual total war setup, which some people may like if they couldn't get to grips with the other games. Tactics are not lacking, but are more arcade like rather than being realistic... however, the context of the game allows for it. If, however, you played Total War solely for tactical combat or Empire building, then you may be dissapointed. Traditional economy building is streamlined to the point of it being over simplified for some factions, or pointless for others as they replace it with their own unique mechanic - which is actually good. If anything it is the streamlining of things that makes the traditional economies and empire building seem boring, whilst the quirky races stand out as being new and fresh experiences.   The grand campaign is badly balanced. Having played all races on the top two difficulties I can say that they scale from easy to hard as so: Dwarfs, Orcs, Empire, Vampires, Chaos. An example being, it is almost impossible for Chaos to win seiges against fully upgraded Dwarf cities on Legendary during the end game, because they simply cannot build enough momentum with their play style to challenge the Dwarfs. Dwarfs in general do appear broken in the campaign, with the AI sometimes gravely showing your odds against them being much higher than they actually are. This leads to both auto resolve losses and impossible encounters where you simply cannot break the Dwarf army. As such a good stratergy for Chaos and Orcs is to always wipe out the Dwarfs first, as the other races are balanced fine in the campaign mode.   Each race does play differently, which is great, and there is major replayability to the game. As much as Atila? Probably not, actually, because the only race that was an actual challenge on legendary was Chaos. I wouldn't want to play the others more than on time, because the way the races go becomes predictable. With DLC coming out this should make warhammer more replayable, but as of yet the DLC which has been released (Beastmen) appears lackluster and expensive... it would have been better if a race such as wood elves would have been released, as that would have offered something 100% different to the game. As it stands Beastmen are a horde army that act slightly different to chaos, despite being chaos in the games lore, and have their own bestiary (hence the price...) Beastmen were never a popular army in tabletop, so it is a strange choice, that is also expensive for the user. I want to buy it for the experience, but... it is Beastmen...   The other dissapointing thing is that magic doesn't swing games as much as it does in the table top, apart from spells which can be used to sniper other characters. You could use your entire magic reserve and only make a slight dent in one unit, or use it all to kill a hero or lord outright. Buffs and debuffs for units also don't stack up very well because they are so short. Spells which dissrupt ranks as a feature also seem lacklustre. I don't quite understand the thinking behind how this is balanced, and whilst the spell effects feel like the table top versions, their effectiveness doesn't reflect the table top at all, apart from the sniper spells.

So here we have a combination of two legendary titles: 'Total War' series and Warhammer Fantasy Battle.   I'm a fan of TW series since first 'Shogun' and first 'Medieval'. The best titles for me are 'Rome' and 'Medieval II' because of excellent settlement development system. Unfortunatelly this system has been completely changed in later games.  I'm also a fan of Warhammer Battle system since 5th edition with nice collection of Bretonia army.   My first impression is that this game is far from being complete. None of my favorite Warhammer nations (except for Undead/Vampires) have been included as playable factions so far (all 3 Elven factions and Bretonia - although there are mods enabling Bretonia but without proper tech tree, specific events and storyline). There is only a small part of WH world avaiable as a campaign map so far and all playable factions still lack many units and special characters. So I'm still waiting for more and more DLCs...  My general impression is that I really enjoyed playing this game (even in this incoplete stage) both as a WH and TW fan. I really felt Warhammer atmosphere and implementation of TW system here is not that bad. I've played only as Empire and Bretonia so far. The simplified settlement development system is similar to 'Shogun 2' and 'Rome II' but although I hated it in those games, I don't mind it here - WHFB is after all a tactical game, so anything on strategic (campaign) scale is a nice addition.   On tactical level this game is very similar to earlier TW titles, like 'Rome II' but with addition of fantasy beasts, magic and special (powerful) characters. On campaign level the game also reasambles its predecessors but with addition of some storyline. Also there is an important distinction in this game - factions vary A LOT in terms of strategic possibilities and gameplay. The differences are NOT just cosmetic and are much deeper than just different unit roster.  Pros: + The very fact someone actually developed this game - I had been waiting for this for many, many years. + Very good graphics and animations both on tactical and campaign scale. + Nice music. + Good Warhammer atmosphere and immersion with significant differences in gameplay experience between different factions. + As with all TW games - HUGE potential for modding (which has always been very easy with this series).  Cons: - The game needs a lot of additions to be actually complete and debugged. - Those additions will probably come in form of many expensive DLCs. - Nice music - yes, I know this was in 'pros' but honestly, 'nice' is a minimum for such game. I really expect such game to have 'EPIC' music, not just 'nice'.  I'm not putting simplified strategic options in 'cons' since this is not 'Europa Universalis', this is still a 'Total War' game and the entire series has always been very simple on strategic side.  OVERALL: This game is 'a must have' for any Warhammer Fantasy Battle fan, and a title worth considering for anyone who likes strategy games in fantasy setting.

Baby's First Total War game; the single player campaigns have nowhere near the depths of previous titles, with the strategic and management gameplay cut down to next to nothing, but they're still fun - if a lot more arcady. Co-op and versus campaigns are fun, but the two player limit holds them back from being truly special. The lack of playable factions is a real drawback, but more are being added through a mix of paid and free DLC; which is acceptable to me, as the different races do play quite distinctively.   Luckily there are mods which remove the regional occupation restrictions of the base game, and ones which unlock more factions too; which give the campaigns far more replayability. However don't expect to see any Medieval 2 style total conversion mods; the modding tools just don't support them yet.   The non-campaign multiplayer is weak; which is disappointing as they could have taken a lot from the miniature game, such as the point system, unit customisation, or army painting.   Siege battles are utterly appalling and by far the worst part of the game; they just consist of the AI running headlong at machine gun like towers, or allow the attacking player to easily cheese the AI by attacking only a small section of wall and ignoring most of the overpowered towers, they are the least interesting siege battles in the series to date, and are a major step back from the otherwise weak Total War: Attila, not to mention that there is essentially only about three variants of city with either a single straight, or a right angled, section of wall to defend/attack, with either 1 or 2 gates. Sieges are so cut back that it's not even worth going in to the specifics as it would take too long to describe.  Magic doesn't add anything meaningful to the game as it’s consistently underpowered, and just generally boring.   TL:RD Worth playing as its fun, but lacking the strategic depth, features, and elegance of the best total games; with what features it does add to the series being at best mediocre.   P.S it’s fun to see the Total War things moving around and stuff ._.

Total War, Warhammer is certainly both a step forwards and backwards for the Total War Series. It integrates a forward thinking uniqueness to the designing of the various factions of the game, and in so doing, creates an immersive element that hasnt really been seen in Total War before. Playing as the dwarves, for instance, it's always fun to watch the great Dwarven Citadels rise from nothing in the mountains, and to destroy the stupid greenskins who have occupied your holds, settling yet another grudge whilst doing so. Warhammer never has a bland, over arching unit or tech tree, and each race is designed to incorperate both strengths and weaknesses for players to utilize and overcome respectively. In addition, this is the first game with flying units, and they make a spectacular difference for the races that have them in combat. Furthermore, the players Generals are brought back to a 'front lines' position that they haven't been at since before Mideval II, and will cut down everything in front of them as long as you back them up with other troops.  There are a few cons to be noted though. For example, the campaigns, for the most part, are honestly somewhat short and underwhelming. 150 turns in as the dwarves and I'd burned every human settlement in the world to ashes, and reestablished the long lost Dwarven Kingdom to past the heights of it's pre-game glory. admittedly, the other campaigns are quite a bit longer, but eventually the uniqueness of the nation you play as makes it so that everything else you just have to burn to the ground. An understandable decision, and one easily fixed by mods, but annoying nonetheless. The quest system makes sense, but in honesty is rather pointless. Aside from the Chaos faction, most hero quests make you wander across the whole of the map with your best generals so that you can get the best weapons and armor equipped for them. By the time you can feesibly do this in most cases, it's rather a moot point becasue you've already killed everyone that you'd need to use a sword on. Finally, the nations of the campaign are rather limited. In previous games, the developers could select various cultures and historical nations to become availible with DLC after the initial game, but that's going to be hard to do with Warhammer. Most of the factions on the campaign map are subservient to a few factions that are already availible, with very few exceptions. There will undoubtedly be DLC to make these factions availible, but I honestly don't think I'll get the feeling of palying a brand new game with them like you might if you played the more recent Total War Games after a new DLC.  All in all, it is a good game, but not quite a great one. In honesty, it feels like they're testing concepts in this game more than anything else, which isn't something I mind in the least. My personal hope is that the Total War Devs will blend together the flying mechanic in this game with the artillery of Shogun 2 to make a decent, more modern era Total War. I'd also wager that whoever does a LoTR conversion for the game will become ridiculously popular overnight, and I will download that as soon as it comes out. I have no doubt, however, that regardless of the success of this game, Total War will continue it's forays into the fantasy realm, and I personally eargerly look to see what they do with it.

Okay, so from looking at the top, you'll see I recommend the game.  It's a fun game, I love the battles, I love a lot of the unique units from the normal Total War games. Steam Tanks are awesome, I love the Helblasters, and I love the epicness of watching the Empire's forces clash with the Warriors of Chaos.  That being said, there are some things I deem pretty wrong with the game  First of all, I seem to suck at battles. The auto-resolve is often better than I am. However, I still win almost every battle I fight unless incredibly outnumbered. I can just waltz my army up to the leader of the Warriors of Chaos', in a straight line, melee front, Steam tanks and Helblasters behind, taking fire from their Helcannons the whole way, and wreck their entire army, only losing one entire unit. Granted, I micromanage and pit units against what they counter, for example I will pit halberdiers against cavalry, greatswords against enemy halberdiers, etc, but it still feels just too easy even when I'm complete trash. Battles are also very short, it would be fun to have longer battles and bigger maps.  Campaign movement. I find that the AI rarely wants to ACTUALLY fight me directly, I have to corner them into it every single time. The Warriors of Chaos walked through my entire territory and did absolutely nothing because they were too busy trying to avoid fighting my armies chasing them. The AI uses hit and run tactics to burn your villages into ruins and then leave. There's no real strategy to it, they just try to cut your infrastructure out from under you. Most of them don't even capture the territory, they just turn it into a ruin. The issue with campaign movement is that the enemy can almost always move slightly further than I can, unless I'm hallucinating or something, so if I follow directly behind an enemy army they will get further and further ahead of me until they escape or I corner them using 2-3 other armies. Direct engagements are extremely rare.  Morale. While I think morale is something very good in games like this, morale is super underpowered. A couple Steam Tanks firing at a unit will break its morale in seconds. The morale system was made arbitrary for this game, units will break at full strength, walk to the edge of the map, and recover to rejoin the battle.  I love the game, the battles are still great to watch, I have a lot of fun building armies and throwing them against the hordes, but I also find it incredibly frustrating to have to chase down the parts that I love about the game. If you don't like playing chicken with an orc army for 5-8 turns trying to corner it, this probably isn't your game unless they patch the AI.

I own every Total War game, I haven't pumped enough hours in but enough to understand the differences. Basically, Total War Warhammer is a 'dumbed' down version of Total War. This game is simplified. Lots of detailed features missing. I mean lots of DETAIL. They took out destructable walls, traps, detailed empire management, formations, and quite a few other thing. However, in my opinion this is all made up because of the Warhammer units. The Warhammer units are a FANTASTIC edition to actual gameplay components. Unit statistics and variations translate well! These models are also extremely well done. Everything looks fantastic. You will not get a better looking Total War game than this. They also added spells! These spells make the game really shine. It adds a layer of depth past Spear beats Cavalry, Sword beats spear, Cavalry beats Sword, etc gameplay. Also an entire new type of unit, Monsters! Adding even further depth!  So what basically happens in this game is the campaign quality goes down but the flat out battle quality goes up. Personally I can deal with the lack of campaign detail since I have the other Total War games anyway. For me this is all about the Warhammer units. Also owning this game does not keep you from going back to the previous Total War titles, in fact it makes me go back to all of them! The changes make you appreciate what was done before and what is new. This game won't trump the other games. It is definitely a great addition to the series though.

TL:DR this game is the perfect combination of Total War and Warhammer. I'd highly recommend this game to fans of both. I cant wait till the whole series is out.  This game is the perfect crossover that I had always dreamed of seeing and whats even better is that CA have done a great job of turning this into a really enjoyable game. Its the first non-historical Total War game and it feels like a breath of fresh air for the series. There arent as many playable factions but the factions that are here are more diverse and play quite a bit differently to each other, compared to factions in the historical titles which were largely similar but with a few different unts.  You have the human Empire faction,which is probably the most similar to the traditional TW factions in other games with a good mix of infantry,cavalry and ranged. The Dwarfs lack cavalry but have excellent ranged and strong infantry with the book of grudges being their unique feature where you have to settle grudges with other factions or suffer a penalty. The Vampire Counts lack ranged nits but can raise undead units for quick reinforcements as well as spreading Vampiric corruption on the campaign map to decrease public order in enemy provinces. And finally the Orcs who also have a decent mix of unit types bt can suffer attrition from infighting if you dont keep fighting and raiding.   The game also has hero characters and lords which can be levelled up with new abilities and equipped with weapons and armour with unique lord characters having their own quest battle story chains. Magic also makes its TW debut and is handled quite well with spell cooldowns and miscasts if you over use a spell.  Good points: - The factions feel unique enough from each other to be interesting and to offer different challenges and playstyles. There are some really fun units like flying monsters and giants for example that add more tactical options than previous TW games. - The campaign is pretty good with the Chaos incursions in the latter part of the campaign offering a challenge that can make the late campaign a lot more interesting. The quest battles are also good and give the players some useful rewards for completing them. -This game is optimized a lot better than Attila was and I love the unit and map design that really brings the Warhammer universe to life. - The heroes and lords are handled well with heroes being useful both as agents on the campaign map as well as being embedded in your armies for use in battles. The leveling system is also great and makes you really feel invested in your generals.  Bad points: - sieges still feel a bit underwhelming though they still play better than in previous TW games. - the AI has a tendency to spam agents against you and this gets pretty annoying

It's an excellent game, and it mixes the Total War and Warhammer Fantasy franchises really well. I'll go through the good, the bad, and the ugly, because that's an easy gimmick for a review you're not going to read.  Good: the biggest unit variety in the Total War series so far allows for a more interesting battle system than ever before. It also means each of the 4 factions has a meaningfully different campaign, which gives you a lot of content for the price. The addition of magic, monsters, flying units, and heroes allows for a fresh dynamic to the series. The campaign, though streamlined, offers a reasonable challenge and is decently accessible. The writing, such as it is, is also top notch: CA's decision to poach the lead writer for White Dwarf has been totally vindicated, and the characterisation of the Warhammer Fantasy universe is near-perfect. Finally, the game is deliberately moddable, so many small annoyances are easily removed. You are buying this, in part, for access to those mods, and they're a part of the product.  Bad: AI has never been perfect in the Total War series, and it's not perfect here. There are a number of small annoyances that will become clear, and not all of them are moddable. Some of them should be addressed in patches to come, but beware. In particular, campaign AI is notorious for knowing exactly where your armies are (and therefore being impossible to engage in battle on your terms) while you are constrained by a fog of war, and its agents receive considerable and frustrating buffs compared to yours. On the battlefield, the AI has little understanding of magic's nuances (it is not a simple system) and is easily tricked into stupid positions, especially when defending. Unit pathfinding also isn't ideal, with the chasing of routing units and the flying unit pathfinding being particularly problematic.  Ugly: Concerns have been raised about the DLC structure for the game. While 'DLC for DLC' won't be released, some are concerned about the cost of new factions, among other things. It's not clear that CA is price-gouging so much as reflecting the expensive development costs, but do bear it in mind if you have a particular hankering to play a non-standard warhammer faction. As with all things Total War, everything will eventually be on sale at -75%, so don't get too agitated. In the game already, the removal of matched combat animations in most cases can make hero-on-hero fights look pretty bad, and the streamlining of campaign building mechanics can in some cases make things too simple (but still not simple enough for the AI to build it right - this can be fixed with mods).  Overall, I'd say it's very good, and please bear in mind how much modding plays a part in fixing minor grievances. It's as polished as any Total War game has ever been, and it merges two exciting franchises together in a very impressive way. The base game, whatever the DLC concerns may be, is very good value indeed.

WFB games come and go, some better than others, but it's the story behind them that remains their greatest strength. CA has taken this concept and run with it. The entire game - though another title in the Total War series - drips with Warhammer flavor. From the specific faction mechanics to the unique army compositions I have personally enjoyed every game of TW: W I've played (even the losing ones). Artillery is a special favorite for me, I always find myself laughing when I see a Greenskin take a direct hit from a Dwarf Cannon, or an Empire line break against Goblin Doom-divers.  The terrain is beautiful, how it changes based on which faction controls it is such an interesting touch that makes the world feel more alive than a simple map. The in-battle scenery is eye catching as well. CA has done a wonderful job at capturing the magnitude of the Old World in its varied battle maps.  The only negative I have with the title is the DLC model. I can see the game being fairly expensive a year down the road, I hope (but don't expect) the price of DLCs to reduce over time to allow an easier entry for newer players years down the road. An amazing game. My experience is the early part of the Orc campaign, a few large scale test battles and a solid (ongoing) coop campaign using the legendary lord start positions with both of us playing as Vamps.  I am a complete stranger to the Warhammer universe but always thought the Total War games would do well with the fantasy setting (mainly due to the scale of the possible battles).    PERFORMANCE: The game itself runs extremely smoothly for me with no hiccups. The only performance note is the loading screens seem to take a LOT longer than Rome 2 (ie comfortably over a minute) but everything outside is smooth as silk (on max or close to)  The AI turns are extremely quick (unlike the early Rome 2 days) so there is almost no waiting time between turns.   GAMEPLAY: The fantasy setting works even better than I thought it would and it appears that the Warhammer setting fits perfectly (from my uneducated in Warhammer background). The racial differences are highly significant and increase replayability several fold in comparison to previous TW titles.   While I loved the historical games; different cultures still always felt pretty similar. In this game the gameplay is completely different between races. eg: Chaos play quite similar to the Mongol horde (ie. no towns) Vampires raise dead, don’t have morale but have a 'binding' so the low morale equivalent means the army starts decaying (so if you beat a vampire army they will be pretty much 100% wiped out) Orcs can spawn AI follower armies; require ongoing war to be happy etc.  I also very much appreciate how asymmetric the battlefield is; eg. Vampires have no ranged units at all. Dwarves are almost overpowered in melee; even ranged units are solid fighters etc. These gameplay differences also affect how you execute your diplomatic strategy (or don’t at your peril). Maintaining more than one Vamp army is extremely expensive so (combined with the ability to raise dead) the strategy we are finding most effective is cunning diplomacy while consolidating resources followed by lightning strikes then reconsolidation.   DIPLOMACY: On the diplomacy note I have found more than any other TW game this has forced me to consider diplomatic actions as well as purely intermittent talks. As an example pacifying the Bloody Spearz orcs involved a few bribes and frequent diplomacy supported by raiding and sacking dwarven cities aligned to the Bloody Spearz’s current conquest aims. This worked very well and has allowed a (begrudging) working relationship.  While the above may very well have been true in earlier games, it never felt like it was needed. In previous games I have found diplomacy to be ‘spam trade agreements’, extort money/pander until you are allies. Combined with the unique racial diplomacy lines, this game manages to make diplomacy a much more interesting and indeed vital part of the game.   RPG Elements: The heroes on the battlefield are a great addition; while I didn’t really like the addition of significant General abilities in previous titles, it works quite well with the hero units in the form of spells etc. Further, the levelling mechanic also brings in quest chains at higher levels for specific equipment so that is a nice touch to add a bit more of a fantasy RPG feel to the generally familiar Total War gameplay (without negatively affecting it).   Overall this is an excellent game. I have had zero issues (apart from the initial load which took a while; due in part I understand to day one server overload) and the aesthetics of fantastical races in huge battles is perfect. If you are a fan of TW games or general fantasy strategy/RPG, definitely worth a closer look. As always, check out gameplay videos etc to make sure it is right for you but for now, I look forward to sinking a LOT more time into this!

First of all: I'm a big fan of the Total War series as well as the Warhammer Fantasy universe. Seeing them come together was a great thing to see anyway, but I think it's interesting for players who like either (or none) of these two things as well. So far, I haven't bought any of the DLCs that cost money, as only the Chaos Warriors have a price I can bring myself to pay for a game that already cost 60€. But I understand that implementing this huge variety of mechanics for each individual faction makes it harder to just put them up for cheaper. I think this game gave the Total War games a major leap forwards, and hopefully Creative Assembly will be able to use a bunch of these entirely new features in their upcoming historic Total War game.  If you don't like Total War in General: Total War Warhammer can be as story driven as you want. There are many main- and side quests that actually give each campaign an individual touch. In that sense, it reminded me quite a bit of the Heroes of Might & Magic series. Also, there is a MUCH greater variety among factions. After all, only one faction is actually humans, and dealing with the stats of non-human combatants is certainly an interesting experience.  If you don't like Warhammer Fantasy/Fantasy games in general: As mentioned above, using and fighting non-human combatants is an interesting experience, even to very experienced Total War veterans. While you can certainly rely to a high degree on your knowledge about tactics and strategies, it also gives you more space to explore and learn about the game.  If you like neither: Total War - Warhammer certainly can still fit what you look for in a strategy game. Sadly, there are not multiple ways to win (like economic or cultural victory), but besides that, it gives you a lot of freedom to play it like you want, ignoring/focusing on features you dislike/like.  Hope that helped someone.

Unlike other Total War games, where gameplay innovations must outshine the stunning lack of diversity and effort put into the core armies and factions themselves, Total War: Warhammer starts with a good unit roster and a very good core campaign. The game overall runs well, looks nice, and does capture the Warhammer feel. However, it's not without it's problems. First and foremost: the game, since some actual work had to be put into the different armies and factions this time, has an incredibly small unit roster to choose from, and are missing some very important types of soldiers in the  Warhammer lore, such as the Blood Knights for the Vampire faction, and the Questing knights for Bretonnia. At this point, I would even say that I have more units from mods than from the vanilla game (although the community appears only to be interested in making more of the same units for the Empire, which is dissapointing at the very least). Second, and one of the issues that there was so much fuss about, is that CA (those absolute imbeciles) cut out a core race from the game to sell as DLC - the Chaos. Now normally, I can understand when some things are cut out of a game to sell as DLC. Developers are people, and people need to eat. However their choice in cutting out Chaos was a mistake. They could have chosen the Dwarves or the Vampire Knights or Bretonnia to cut out - all three of which the game would be semi-complete without - and it wouldn't have been nearly as much of a bother.   I just realized how lengthy this review was getting, so I'll cut to the chase.  Pros: +Unit diversity +Good graphics +Nice, rounded campaign +Good incorporation of the Warhammer universe +Epic, large battles +Nice environmental diversity  Cons: -Lack of units -Lack of factions -Odd gameply decisions (seemingly limited to the campaign, at least) -Incomplete factions/unit rosters -Poor DLC decisions -Battles are way too fast  Overall: A solid 3/5.  Not outstanding, but certainly fun. I would recommend the Chaos DLC solely because the game just isn't complete until you've played as the Chaos.
