Comparing myself to other Total War fans and players I seem to have a different point of view than most. For reasons I don't understand the Shogun games were rated higher than the Medieval 2 game - I suppose there are features and details taken into account that I do not.  I despise Shogun, there's absolutely nothing dynamic about it and no reason to play it a second time(in my opinion) because all the factions are the same. They all have the same units.  Medieval 2 I still play to this day. Why? Not for graphics or it's potential(even with an i7 quad core, the game still won't bring in extra armies stating I need a better processor), but it's because of the dynamic qualities of the game. The Scottish are -nothing- like the Moores, for example.  If you're like me and you enjoy the dynamic, varied qualities of the different factions and countries and you happen to be a fan of the base fantasy archetypes created by Tolkien then you might enjoy Warhammer as much as I do.  The game is more individually centered, meaning individual soldiers or heroes tend to have a huge influence, opposed to the semi-historical games opposed where you are much better off protecting your general than sending him in on the front lines. So, tactics and strategy will require adjusting, but I admit, as a fan of the fantasy genre and of Total War in general, I absolutely adore Total War Warhammer.  For example, the 'Greenskins' are essentially the armies of Mordor, as we know it from Lord of the Rings. They share much more in common than they are different. In fact, you'll find those archetypes(like the ring wraiths or Aragorn's undead army, the dwarf factions, etc) are all over the game and are so similar that it has given me pause at times wondering how it isn't a copyright issue.  It's a visually cinematic game. I find myself watching the fights more than actually leading sometimes, just because it's so cool watching a giant vampire monster smash through a company of soldiers for example. And it's replayability is very high, elements of randomness mixed with what is no less thn 50+ starting factions(of all races), some of them friendly and others not-so-friendly. So, it's not as if the -only- human faction you will face is 'The Empire' only, there are a number of other factions that can potentially grow to a major power.  The game is also very 'smash mouth' compared to other Total War games. Depending on the units, many of them are super heroes basically and will sustain a fight where anything short of, say in Medieval 2 terms dismounted Fuedal Knights, would break the fight and run. So there are a lot of very powerful, sometimes individual units instead of large companies.  There are some cons though.   I would prefer the seige battles were a little less airy, meaning it's very easy, compared to other titles, to attack a city and win.  The defending side no longer will flee to the center of town either, there are avenues of escape surrounding the battle map, so a unit could 'run away' back into the city and take itself out of the fight.  Apart from that? It's the first Fantasy Total War game and it's fantastic.  There may be some balancing issues as well. A 'full' army of humans will never equal a 'full' army of undead, for example. The Vampire Lords have too many very powerful units. But this is offset as the Vampire Lords armies are very expensive and so there will naturally be far less of them than other factions. If I were going to fight a 'full' Vampire Lords army it would need to be with at least 2 human armies, complete with plenty of cannon and ranged and it's better defensive units... and hopefully a good leader and spell caster.  Thus far in my short time playing, I have yet to lose a fight with the Vampire Lords, much less than that, I have yet to lose a single Terrorgeist(bone dragon basically) or Varghulf(sp? giant vampire monster). They are very powerful and I essentially use them as pivot points to allow the smaller units to engage and weaker, faster units to flank.  I love the Total War games, with the exception of a few titles(as they lack the dynamic qualities of others) and Warhammer is probably my favorite of them all. If this is your first Total War game, I recommend trying Medieval 2 first, it's cheap and still very good(also playable on much older pc's, my dual core laptop can run it).  10/10

The long and short of this is that this game is fantastic and I highly recommend it.   As for more details, here we go:  System Specs: I exceed minimum entirely and I match reccomended on processor and memory, falling short on graphics card. That said, the game runs with no issues once it gets loaded, which is a little slower than Rome 2 to load but still faster than Shogun 2 to load, which had the longest load time I can recall on any TW game.  Total War Fans: This game is great, it really is. Agents can now fight when embedded into an army, lesser towns can have walls but don't have to have, the Campaing AI is -ok- if a touch slow while the battle AI is -very good- actually flanking with cavalry and supporting their archers. You cannot garrison cities without leaving a general in that city, which can make managing public order a little harder than it has to be, but it isn't terrible. There are faction specific movies again, which is nice. All in all this is a very solid Total War game. OH! and you can rename cities and heroes. Pretty nifty.  Warhammer Fans: This game brings the races and creatures to life in a beautiful way. I honestly cannot wait for, and truly hope for, a blood and gore DLC to really bring home the Hammer, but even without it its fun to watch the fights. Units are well balanced and keep much of their flavor. Flying units exist, giants and monsters, even magic and mech. There are quests for legendary lords and loads of lore for those who want it.  I only have ~40 hours in at this point (compared to ~500 in Rome 2) but I can already tell you this is going to be one of my favorite games for quite a long time.

This game is fantastic. As a big computer strategy fan and Warhammer tabletop fan, this hits both of those interests square on. The graphics are great - watching a monster throwing humans around like bean bags as they desperately try to flee a routed encounter is priceless. The strategy is pretty deep as well - there's the map-level turn-based HoMM/AOW-style strategy, and then there's the large scale RTS of combat encounters.  It's not perfect - but it was a super clean relatively bugless launch, and some of the quirks (Invocation of Nehek seeming to do nothing) were promptly fixed in the first patch. I 'get it' with the anger over the DLC, but the content in the base game is extensive and great, the factions are logical, and importantly, they inherent the very distinct strengths and weaknesses of their tabletop counterparts! The factions ARE distinct in this. It is VERY meaningful to the strategies you use (as a whole, and on an encounter-by-encounter basis depending on the opposing team you are up against).  I highly recommend it

So I don't really like CA or their business practices. It is a pretty sketchy deal they run: 'Here is our new game, immediately with this DLC faction! One month later, pay a few dollars and add lack luster blood graphics to the game. Then we will have another fresh DLC for you to buy, etc, etc.' At least with Warhammer, the DLC will be a little more unique than asking players to pay for factions already in the game (maybe, not sure what is happening with Bretonnia).  That said, the extra expenses and balance issues in multiplayer do re-create the Games Workshop table top experience. At least I am staying in my depth as a long time GW customer.  But even after all that saltiness and angry net growling, I can't help but really enjoy this game. It is a lot of fun.   Most of my bitterness comes from the knowledge that I am going to pay for the stupid blood pack (well, maybe. It doesn't look that good) and probably every other race DLC because the game is fun and this is the best Total War game in years. The races play unique from one another and, despite much of the complaining, having certain factions not be able to take other factions' territories makes diplomacy a lot more valid and helps combat the everyone invades everyone problem. The civilized races uniting against Chaos incursions in the campaign adds focus and narrative and the addition of magic, which needs some balancing (giant, high cost fire/death tornadoes that are difficult to aim do pitiful damage even when they connect, while cheaper, target and forget spells decimate heroes and entire units), works really well in these big battles.  So come ready to spend some money and you should find an enjoyable experience if you like either Total War games of the past or the Warhammer Fantasy Universe.

After playing for about 100 hours i think it is time for me to give this game an honest review.  This just might be one of the greatest Total War game i have ever had the honor of playing. The game runs like silk and only lags in huge 3v3 battles and even then it is very little. The models and textures are absolutely gorgeous on Ultra and great on High. The gameplay is like other Total War games but with a few twist. Now you have to worry about HUGE beast ripping through your lines and even better, flying creatures. Now, I was very skeptical when I learned about flying things. I wondered if CA would be able to pull it of and I was blown away when a verghiest landed and quickly decimated belthasar gelt. Right there I knew that this was one of the greats that would insta go into my favorites. There are so many good things about this game but I do have a few complaints.  Day one i had trouble even running the game but of course it was fixed in around 10 mins. Other than that i could not seem to find any other glitches or bugs and still have found none. Now on to my complaints on the game at the moment. Chaos is my absolute favorite nation to play as but boy is it infuriating. around turn 20 i had around 13-16 full stacks chasing me around the map. It wouldn't be a problem if it wasn't nations on the oither side of the map leaving their borders to attack my 2 stacks. I dont mind having to fight 2v5 if the 5 is the people closest to me not the empire and its allies leaving their borders unprotected to chase me. After i escapes and dominated the north i went to the empire and found that all of their cities excluding their capital was under britonias control. (Surprise!) The other semi complaint is the diplomacy. I dont know how to feel about it. It is imposible to do anything unless you give 30k-40k. If i offer the ai a trade agreement where they will make 300 a turn and i will make 84 and offer them 10k they should not say no and then declare war on me. My last one is that the orcs need better early game units. They seem to get stomped by the dwarfs every game only surviving by confederatin with others and being everywhere. I know dwarfs should be able to 1v3 orc units and agree with it I do beleive that the orcs are a little too weak early on. A potential fix may be to give them bolt throwers? That is about it for my review. I would recomend this game to anyone who loves Warhammer or Total War. 11/10

This is not a review of CA's and /or SEGA's dlc practices, but of the game itself.  For once in the series, the factions are actually diverse. They all play and feel differently, as well as offer - or require - different tactics. Combat feels quite fast-paced, if not too much so, especially compared to previous titles. It is an issue for some people however, and I can't blame them. Perhaps you just need to get used to it, I've no idea. Some gameplay features are somewhat streamlined or simplified - like the city management, yet, in general, it doesn't end up impacting the gameplay in a too negative way. Performance is surprisingly good. After Attila, I was worried about barely-playable FPS and ridiculous turn timers. And - nothing. On my not-so-modern rig FPS only dips in massive battles, and you don't have to wait ages for AI to process their turns, even in the late-game.  Aside from a few issues here and there, what's already in the game works quite well. But there's not enough of it yet. Current 6 playable races are nothing compared to the (planned) 16. As fun as the Grand Campaign is, it's still in need of new content.  Now, the DLCs. My opinions on the pricing aside, DLCs that add new races are good stuff. They're no longer vain palette-swaps with one-two 'new' units. If you're interested in using a certain race - buy it on a discount. If not, you'll still encounter them in Grand Campaign or MP.  Simply having them around adds a lot, even if it's a Horde that may or may not get wiped out 15 turns into the campaign.  All in all, a solid 7.5 /10 with great potential, it does justice to both Warhammer Fantasy and Total War series. Would kill them /raise them again.

Definitely my favorite Total War game thus far. The combination of fantasy with classic total war mechanics works better than I could have expected. I can't wait to see what type of mods can be produced for this game eventually (I'm crossing my fingers for another 3rd age total war!)  I liked how the grand campaign victory conditions were a lot more reasonable than in certain more recent total wars. In Rome 2 and Attila in particular it felt like you had to conquer literally everything to win. In TW Warhammer, you never get the feeling that you're the strongest, nobody can match you, but you're only halfway towards satisfying victory conditions. (Actually that can happen for Dwarfs and Greenskins, but not as bad as before).

Overall, a highly enjoyable port of the tabletop game to the PC RTS genre.  I am a longtime Warhammer fan (grew up playing 40K tabletop), and this is a really enjoyable representation of it on PC. The emphasis on lore is apparent throughout the game, and the idiosyncrasies of Games Workshop's approach to fantasy really shines. If you're a Warhammer fan who hasn't bought the game, it's very much an enjoyable jump back into the universe.  I also highly enjoy the gameplay. The game seems centered around the campaign, where you choose a race and one (of typically two) leaders, and then are given a starting city and army. The campaign is played on a turn based strategic map, where you manage armies and cities, with real time battles in an RTS format. The economics and strategy have a mild learning curve, but a few hours is enough to figure out how to be fairly successful. The RTS battles also have a moderate learning curve, and as you gain new units or try new races you'll experience fairly radical differences in play style. This really reminds me of the tabletop game, it's nice to see it so well represented.  The base game comes with enough playable factions (Dwarves, Empire, Greenskins, Vampire Counts) that you can experience a wide range of play styles in the RTS battles. I have only played the Dwarf campaign enough to comment on it in depth, but it's definitely enjoyable and I will play the other campaigns in the future. I was able to obtain the base game at a discount, with the chaos warriors DLC, for pre-order, but I think it's well worth full price. Follow-up DLC seems fairly expensive, and I'll likely wait for it to go on sale.

After playing what I would consider a fair amount of time on a Total War game, I went back to the store to see what other TW Fans thought of their newest game. I came expecting maybe some people to have some of the small qualms that I have as well, some minor aspects from older games that are just those 'quality of life' details that are missing and would be GREAT to have on Warhammer ( Like fixed formations, for example ) and these to me are minor issues compared to the overall game and I kind of take it as them moving in a more light hearted and a 'average' gamer friendly approach compared to the more diehard tactical players who played older games....  BUT INSTEAD I see a slew of negative reviews based on the DLC practices of the TW series. I find this absolutely disgusting, not only are you hurting the image of a game you love, you're doing it out of spite when LITERALLY THE ENTIRE VIDEO GAME INDUSTRY DOES THE SAME THING. I understand, I really do, this is the biggest grumble from gamers in our day and age but does hurting the rating of your go-to-game REALLY going to change this common practice? You're lying to yourself if you think so.   The TW series, in my opinion, is the greatest RTS you could ever ask for, and although I do not support the DLC practices, I do understand them. It's just what is going on, and not all of gaming is the 'gamer' side of gaming. It's a business too, and I'm sure if the producers of such a fine product had a say in it, there'd be far less DLC and more FLC.  Long story short, although Warhammer as a TW game has left me feeling like some bit is lacking, on the other hand they've opened up a FANTASY universe to players who've only played Historical based games, and brought the love of strat with them. The combat is fun and exciting, the magic is actually balanced ( at least, in my opinion ) and adds a variety to the field. The Warhammer lore is fascinating and grabbing. For people who would review this game as BAD because of a business perspective are just insulting the rest of the loyal fans who enjoy the work put into this game.

A blast to play and the battles just work how they should - like they used to back in the day before Rome 2 etc. CA have created something special here by going back to their roots, all the while adding in some great new features. And before anyone says anything - I'm not a CA fan boy and was as disappointed with Rome 2 as the next man.  System specs (so you can compare):  i7 6700k 4Ghz 32gb Corsair Dominator ram 6gb ASUS ROG 980ti Gigabyte Gaming G1 mobo Samsung M.2 SSD Windows 10  PROS:  - Great smooth graphics in both map and battles on ultra settings - Battle AI massivley improved from Rome 2 etc - Character skill tree with loads of options - Lords can have loads of different followers and unique armour and weapons applied to them (warhorse for example) - Heros that can affect map provinces, but also be used in battles too - Decent amount of research options - Quests to keep campaign interesting - Many factions to fight (or engage in dimplomacy with) - Brilliant range of units and all very unique for each race - Flying units! nuff said - Your leader actually feels like a leader and can dramatically turn the tide in a battle - Routing units are now sensible enough to stop for a breather once far enough away and will mostly rejoin fight (unlike Rome 2 where they ran away even if there was enough of them to come back and get involved again) - Good amount of buildings to choose from that all play a part in shaping your province/empire - Unique flags that can be assigned to individual units for each battle (this is a great feature and can turn a strong base unit into a devastating unit if applied to the correct one) - Many other cool things that you will have to play to find out!  CONS:  - Map is good, but I feel it could have been a bit bigger. Rome 2 and Attilla felt bigger. Still, it is decent and will take a great leader to conquer - Early days of my first campaign as Empire felt a bit hand-holdy, like they are sending you down a particular pre-determined path (I understand this is kinda how they integrate the tutorial and advance the 'story', but maybe there is a better way for future games) - Chaos arrive by turn 22 in my game, seems a bit early for such a strong devastating race to be introduced - Would have been nice to have more than 4 races to choose from (no doubt DLC will change all that) - Empire on empire battles in early game start to get a bit repetitive as all units are the same and you kinda learn quickly how to win (Empire vs other races is where it no doubt starts to get good)  All in all, I am mightly impressed at how polished the game feels for day one release and am so glad we have a Total War that just feels right again. If CA stick to this formula the future for the other games (Rome etc) looks good. I just hope they do, as they have nailed it this time.

The Warhammer setting is what I've always thought the Total War games were meant to cover. It is this fantasy setting that provides so much more potential than any of the historical eras already covered and it shows in the depth available units for the factions that are available at release. Yet this depth is a two-edged sword. The fan base of Warhammer is a diverse lot, many players have a particular faction they are very attached to. With so my detail to include, it would have been very difficult for the developers to have all units for all factions available in the base game. What they have provided us is a solid selection of the core armies in great detail.  I have yet to explore the campaign portion in great depth. Instead, I have focused on exploring all the units available via custom battles.  Yes, the launch has had some issues. The black screen was encountered by me and all it took was trying again for it to work. Others haven't been so fortunate but there are already some workarounds that appear to mitigate the issue. Performance on my gaming laptop with an Nvidia 780M is adequate when the details are turned down to medium/high and it still looks good. In battle performance seems smooth so far, even with multiple full-card armies rampaging around.  While I am not a fan of DLC in most cases, this game I can fully understand the need to fund the development of the follow-on races. What remains to be seen is if they try to gouge players. Only time will tell.

So, after about 20 hours at a time when I should be focusing on my paper I cannot give this game anything other than a thumbs up. Let's get down to the nitty-gritty.  PROS * Varied unit lists that really does feel like Warhammer Fantasy, be it the undead, the chaos trolls, the flying units, the giants etc etc. Finally we have some real, massive character to the units * A campaign that actually can pack in some story, including storyline battles etc, which is a really neat way to get in the 'historical battles' into a fantasy setting. We have context to the Battle of Agincourt, but not 'The siege of Kakarak ka krak(or whatever, dwarf names are weird) and these campaign mission battles really provides that.  * Magic! (admittedly a little underwhelming but still) * A beautiful world map with lots of details and character * Diplomacy doesn't seem that pants-on-head stupid, which is a plus  CONS * Only five playable races. I understand they are going to make more but still, it's not that varied. (I want my high elves and/or lizardmen) * The system with artefacts seems a bit in need of tweaking. My empire campaign has me overloaded with crap (wonder if you could sell them) * The Story Battles in the campaign can get in the way of campaign game flow: 'Hmm I could take this army to fight this random battle here that'll net me a neat artefacts, or I could take it to stomp those undead guys... eh screw it, I can do that battle later'.  Conclusion Certainly some people will complain and I can't say I don't understand where they're coming from, but I'm having the time of my life right now. It remains to be seen if it'll have the longevity of the other games though, but with each race having a fundamentally unique playstyle, I think I'll be good for a good while longer.

It is a real shame that people are negatively reviewing this game simply because of the issues, as mentioned above, without playing the game first. Why? Because this game is, from the limited time I have played it, absolutely fantastic. From the get go on my Empire campaign I have had a polished, optimised and exciting experience which I have not had since Shogun 2.   The AI has proved a challenge (playing on HARD difficulty), recruiting well balanced armies of infantry, range and cavalry which creates exciting battles which are beautiful to watch. That being said have yet to experience magic being used as I am currently facing off against human factions (refer to other reviews). The AI employs raiding and ambushes on the campaign map and always poses a huge threat to you the player.  I have yet to suffer from any major bugs, although there does appear to be a sound bug around my settlements which sounds like they are being besieged, although they are not. I am sure this will be fixed by CA in the near future. Other than that minor inconveince, I have yet to suffer from game crashes, graphical errors or weird AI behaviour on the battlefield and campaign map.   Overall my early impressions of Total War: Warhammer are very good indeed and I look forward to delving into the game deeper and experience more of what the game offers. I happily recomend this to all.  PS: I know the launch issues are very annoying and it is understandable that you would be angry at not being able to play a game that you have spent money on. Now as I have said a hotfix has been released which supposedly fixes the launch issues. I can personally confirm that I am now able to the launch the game with Steam online. As someone who is fairly acquainted with Creative Assembly and the Total War series, Total War: Warhammer is (in my opinion) their magnum opus. Everything I could have complained about from previous iterations of Total War has been (more or less) fixed:    The AI finally got gud (with some very minor discrepancies)   All factions are incredibly unique, fun to play, and have their own strengths and weaknesses. Even races that didn't interest me personally much (Dwarves, Humans) have turned out to be spectacular, brutal campaigns   Diplomacy feels real and viable for the established setting   Generals (Lords) are incredibly powerful and have a huge impact on the battle   TW:W also includes some very welcome and refreshing features that make this game stand out from predecessors in both the Total War & Warhammer franchises:    Faction & item unique spells & abilities for your Heros/Lords, and faction-unique research trees make for an incredibly varied, tactical and all-encompassing experience both on and off the battlefield   Narrative quests pertinent to the Warhammer universe that reward your Lord with awesome gear   An incredible array of units, from your typical cannon fodder infantry to unique creatures like giants, monstrous cavalry & flying beasts   RPG elements, such as equipable items, followers & mounts   I would definitely recommend this game if you're a Total War or a Warhammer veteran. I would also recommend this game if you're new to either of them.   All-in-all, this is a great game, and worth the full $59.99. As for DLC, CA is notoriously terrible for pushing out pricey, underwhelming DLC...but if all factions coming in future DLCs are as unique and well thought out as the ones already in the game, $8 is...reasonable. That being said, I'd still wait to grab them all in a bundle deal or something, because the starter races are more than enough to give you 300+ hours of solid game time.

Total War: Warhammer  What a game! I just finished winning the Empire Campaign and I have to say this was quite the experience.   PROS:   Graphics are amazing! Unit diversity is really cool for a TW game. The heroes are fun and also makes it quite frustrating when you lose one because there's a huge time investment there. The Lords are similar as above but can totally change the tide of a combat. The action was fast paced for this type of game. I was being attacked in four different directions all over the map. I had no bugs in my entire playthrough. The music was a good compliment to the action. The items on your heroes are very unique and can turn the tide of a battle. It's definitely worth doing the item quests. The battles are really fun and have a lot of great tactics and detail, but by turn 150+ you will mostly auto-resolve.  CONS:  It's VERY hard to get more than 5-6 large armies. The mechanics of the game are limiting in that way, which makes it hard to defend against the Chaos from up North West, North, and North East and the Greenskins and Vampire Counts from the South. I had almost every settlement maxed out to give me gold and it was still hard fielding 6 armies. The long campagin win is longggggggggggggggg. The tech trees make it very difficult to make everything in one province. It would be nice if some of the smaller cities could go up to Level 4 at least--especially in Reiksland.  Summary:  If you like Total War, this is a great game for you. If you like Warhammer, this is a great game for you. I've played both series since Shadow of the Horned Rat came out, and the original TW. This one will be installed for many many years to come.

Mankind are a bunch of idiots. So how on earth did the gods decide we should be allowed to exist? The answer is simple: Its this game! The perfect blend between the beloved Total War series and one of the best fantasy universes out there, the pairing is awesome, both on paper and in execution. Surely a work worthy of the divine!  As a long time Warhammer fan i adore the amount of work and details Creative Assembly has put into staying true to the Warhammer franchise. There is a emmence amount of love put into realising the Warhammer part. Little details in notifications received on the campaing map are constatly putting a smile on my face and sometimes blowing my mind. Little things like that are true to the Warhammer universe in that they use the lore of the setting.  It is truly an experience for instance to have an advisor    who is not just some Gandalf figure existing only to advise you but have motives for doing so. Those motives can be figured out if the game is played in a certain way! And in the world of warhammer that plot makes SENSE!    Another part that i am happy Creative Assembly has gotten right is the dark and sometimes hooligan like humor of the setting. To strike a peace treaty with a very evil faction only for them to announce the sacrifices they will make to celebrate feels haunting.  Another example could be the sometimes brutal beating the games ultimate villain Chaos receive from the local hooligans: The Orcs and Goblins. To see the doomtide run and avoide the slaughter of vile dimwits, or perhaps being forced to plow through the lands of the undead, is a thing that seems almost unique to the Warhammer universe and with this game you can play such a story on the computer! What a time to be alive.  The game offers some unique experiences to veteran Total War players as well. The inclusion of magic and monster units gives a new dimention and depth to the combat system. The campaign map is simple and effective but also the only thing which is lacking in a sense. It is clear that the Warhammer world always has been about the combat in its tabletop form and therefore economy and city management in the setting had to be, lets say 'invented', by the developers. However when ever there is a piece of lore about how ordinary life i spent or where cities or important building are, they are respected and realised.   The battles look stunning! The perk of the fantasy setting is visible here most of all. The only thing there that needs some work perhaps are sieges.  Total War: Warhammer shines in the sense that it shakes up the Total War franchise and makes the Warhammer world come to life in a way that it has never been done before. The developers also seems keen to pop out new contents, some for free others paid, and updates to the game. That fantasy setting has also allowed for unique Total War gameplay.  Verdict: 9.5/10  Last words: I cannot recommend this game enough. And sorry for missing commas english is not my first language!

Heya! This review is specifically made for those peeps wondering similar along the lines of: 'Hmm Total War, I've heard about it, should I buy it?' or 'Ohh! Warhammer in an RTS game style! Should I buy it?'  Answer: First you got to look at the price. Bit steep I know, But I HIGHLY suggest to buy this game if you are, a Hardcore Total War fan, a Warhammer fan or a RTS loving Fan. Total War: Warhammer has all the essentials on being one of the greatest RTS of recent release. And with it's upcoming DLC of Realm of WoodElves, it's sure going to amp up the gamers that are already playing it.  So, this isn't a 'Fast' Review, I'm gonna send out the viable information for a person to either buy this game or completely skip it.  Pro: - Immersive Campaign: If you had known Total War CA company, it's that they love their lore as much as they love their fans. The Campaigns Single or even Multiplayer Campaigns are soooo fun, and it's no less expected from Warhammer's lore intergrated into the Virtual Gaming platform, every characters, actions and locations are all aspects of realms that really gives the player the motivation and inspiration to do his best at all times.  - Races/Rosters/Factions: The fact that CA has made a really balanced gameplay in their games; Shogun II, ATILA, Medieval II is because of the versatile sets of Rosters/Races/Factions, they are all uniquely made to fill different types of uses from different individual players and their play-style. Some perhaps favours some more than others or perhaps they just enjoy everything. The races in Total War: Warhammer uniquely gives the player the accessibility of strategic and tactical gameplay, learning new tricks and curves to potentially win the game.  - Multiplayer: The Multiplayer experience from Campaign to Custom Battles are impendingly exciting to watch. From the classic 1v1 scenario to a 3v3 Scenario in Land Battles, Subterranean and Siege Battles, there's lots of different ways to go about your daily warmongering hunger!  Con: Cost: Possibly the most problematic aspect of the game, CA was notorious on it's sales. For people to pay the same amount for more content released (Beastmen, Grim and the Grave, King and Warlord, BLOOD GORE!) easily gives the game a negative standing. I for one have money to spend, and while the recent releases are understandable in price, Call of the Beastmen, and the Blood Gore dlc are not.   Campaign Player Limit Restriction: A friend of mine REFUSES to play a Total War game that only has two player in it's Campaign. I for one, speculate that CA will intergrate more players in Campaign in the mere future but as of now, the Multiplayer Campaign experience are limited to Two Players only! Bummer!  Map Limitations: The maps are all made wonderiously, a shame that it can't be said toward Siege Battles. The sieges last averagely 15-20 minutes. While most Total War games like Medieval or ATILA can go on about 50-60+ minutes. The Siege is less exciting because of the Inevitable Wall Climb strat as well as the gate being held against the attackers' side. I for one encourage CA to intergrate some sort of variability on InnerWalls rather than have JUST the Exterior Walls.  And that's pretty much all the Predicament I've yet to witness in all honesty. I will be playing more and more and more, briefly updating this review so that people in the future can also be updated upon whether they'd buy this game.  So TL:DR? BUY THE GAME, IT IS COSTLY AND SOME ARE UNREASONABLY EXPENSIVE BUT IF YOU LOVE RTS, TOTAL WAR OR WARHAMMER EXCLUSIVELY AND INCLUSIVELY, IT'S WORTH IT!

So, first things first; this is not a faithful recreation of the Table Top version. If that is what you are expecting or want, then you will be disappointed. Having said that, it is also not wholly unrecognisable either. You have heroes, monsters, magic, and big blocks of infantry and cavalry all charging around having a baller time. All the staple elements of the Table Top game, and without the ball ache of assembling and painting them (or if you're like me, assembling and then NOT painting them).   It is first and foremost, however, a Total War game, with all that implies. So there is nation management: You build things in your cities. You construct armies: picking from a roster of troops (which are admirably different depending on which race you pick - largely no reskins here) and send them out into the world to fight and die for you, and hopefully to conquer a wee bit of land first. There is resource management: buildings, some skills, and some actions (raiding) generate an income, from which you maintain your armies and construct new ones and cities too. If your outgoings exceed your income, expect troops to desert. There are also luxury items, but they don't seem all that useful, except for generating cash.   The strategic view, where most of this stuff happens is largely similar to other Total War games (and, as with most stuff in TW games, is a gradual - and largely positive - evolution). The map seems to be bigger, and graphically more impressive. It is also more Gamesworkshopy too, so mountains are taller, forests darker, spiders are bigger and there are skulls everywhere. It's pretty neat. I like it.   But it's the tactical (battle) view where most of the obvious differences are, and where the game is most familiar to the Plastic Men version. Two armies line up and pummel the living daylights out of each other. In the campaign, it is rarely an equal or fair fight: inevitably, one side is larger, or has better units, or a superior general, or more useful terrain, or all of the above. But that's ok, because it means the strategic view is just as (perhaps more) important. Now, full disclosure: I'm not very good at the battles, even against the AI. I normally require a decent upper hand to win. But again, that's ok.   The battles themselves are a mighty maelstrom of dying and fighting. Big blocks of infantry cluster and charge and counter charge. Heroes smash their way through lesser troops in impressively cinematic sequences, and magic manages to be both important, but not overpowered. Monsters pummel puny line troops and artillery smashes everything. It's good fun.   Negatives. The DLC policy can be tiresome, but there is a decent dripfeed of FLC, and no one is forcing you to buy it all. In fact, I've yet to purchase any DLC, as key mechanics are free, and the paywall tends to be restricted to playing as the new factions.   Some of the quest battles (a largely neat feature) can be unbalanced. And the (spoiler) Chaos invasion at the end seems unstoppable, but was very much a paper tiger, once the AI armies inevitably split up.   it can also be a bit daunting to a newbie, and this should probably not be your first TW game - although it is worth persevering.   Finally, f**k Grimgore Ironhide. That guy is ridiculous.

Now, I should start with a sort of disclaimer. I've heard many things about this game, and most of them seem to be comparing it to previous TW games. Apparently it has been severly 'dumbed down', and lacks the cool features the other games have had. For all I know, this is totally correct. Personally I have only played TW: Napoleon , and not for very long, so when I give this review it is actually emphasising on the 'warhammer' part of 'Total War: Warhammer', rather than the 'Total War' part. Now, with the elongated and mostly useless sort of disclaimer out of the way, my thoughts on the game.  Bloody good fun.  Thats my brief summary of the game. Yes, there are many aspects that need refining;  -DLC is a bit overpriced (Though most of the time adds excellent content) -Diplomacy is less than great. Personally I believe it would benefit if it were something more akin to the Civ5 diplomacy, because as of current options are severely limited and factions that should require diplomacy (Cough cough the Empire) are able to do virtually nothing, as everybody usually hates them and there is no way to surpass them. -And much much more! BUT. and this is the 'but' part. The game is flawed in many ways. However, if you are able to get over these issues, you are left with an incredibly entertaining game. The real-time combat really feels different and fun, in part to the multiple race selections and incredible unit rosters, the fighting and strategies involved vary immensly, from an Orc charge followed by a multitude of giant spiders and kamikazing Goblins (My personal favourite) to versatile elves mixing between hiding in forests and firing at the enemy, before ramming then with Reindeer charges* and giant trees from behind. Oh, and also magic. Gotta love magic during combat. The campaign map is also quite useful and fits the game quite well. I am personally a fan of the province linking system, I find that it simplifies the settlements and is quite handy. That and the diverse landscapes, filled with frozen wastes, lush forests, vast deserts and icy mountain ranges. It's also pretty sweet how certain factions, such as the Vampire Counts, Elves and Chaos influence the campaign map as they conquer, meaning the map is in constant flux. Lastly, what I believe to be a highlight of the game is the modding community. There is such a vast array in the mods available to the game, made by the community. If there's something you don't like about the game (Or many, many things.) then there's usually a mod to alter it to your liking. Or, just, y'know, adds more cow carcasses to be fired from trebuchets. Anything is possible with mods.  So, if you've lasted this long through my waffle of a review, just remember that yeah, this game is flawed. And broken. And has issues. But if you can get past those mostly petty grievances, it's an incredibly fun game.   *No, as far as I gather, the Wood Elves actually get Stags' as mounts, not Reindeer, but they look similar enough that I just want to believe.

TLDR:   Buy it if you are hardcore into Warhammer, don't mind the very steep price tag and you want to read lore and see fantasy armies battle it out.   Pass if you want a reasonably priced strategy game that is deep, involved and fun to play.  You need to use a little foresight when considering a purchase of Total War: Warhammer. We are now seven months post release and there exists $65 worth of DLC at the moment. So, if you're looking for a complete experience consider this a $125 game. Ditto that for part two and three and you are looking at a $375 game. Are you alright with that? If so, read on.   The bread and butter of this game is the animated battles. Bottom line, if you don't care about watching fantasy armies slaughtering eachother in real time you should just save yourself a lot of money and move on right now. The strategy, RPG elements and empire building in this game are nonexistant to barely recognizeable.  Strategy begins and ends with trying to flank a paper unit with your scissors unit. RPG elements begin and end with equiping boring items and putting skill points into (mostly) generic trees for your generals. Empire building begins and ends with deciding which (mostly) generic building trees you want to invest in then you just cut-n-paste across every region you conquer.   Diplomacy is terrible and really just exists as a ton of spam you click through at the beginning of each round. As a dwarf you will get peace treaties from orcs and vampires, as if that makes any sense whatsoever. Vampires may declare war on you one turn then proceed to offer you gold for a peace treaty for the next 30 turns.  The turn-based overland map is so clunky and random there seems to be little purpose outside of looking for battles that you can win. Your limited field of vision ensures enemy armies will constantly run in from the shadows and decimate your cities and armies before you have a chance to react. They exhibit minimal AI and seem to exist as a harassing agent until they are disposed of. The story is barebones, impersonal and largely uninteresting. Their is a very comprehensive encyclopedia of Warhammer lore built into the engine so you can read up on a lot of stuff if that is your scene.  The battles are pretty cool at first. Who can deny the awesomeness of clashing armies in a fantasy universe? Performace is acceptable and the graphics are noteworthy with a decent rig. The highlight is the clashing of armies but they quickly devolve into blops of units with only the front line attacking. Everyone else just sort of stands around waiting for their turn to kill or die. This tends to be immersion breaking if you really dial in to a single battle. Keep the camera moving, however, and you can look past this unfortunate issue. The tedious, redundant nature of the battles are unescapable, unfortunately. The blood and gore DLC is required, in my opinion, to give any sense of soul to these battles. I literally quite playing the game after a few hours because it was an obvious omission that seriously reduced one's level of enjoyment.  Bottom line, battles get boring and they get boring fast. Battle maps are limited and you will never fight in sprawling cities or castle towns. You basically have two battle maps: wilderness or a siege against a single wall. The vast majority of units can only be told where to go or who to attack. No skills, formations or stances mean battles are a click-and-watch affair. Cool for the first few times but TW:W turns into an auto-resolve game very quickly. This is never more true than during the horribly under-developed seige battles. Ugh. What's left is the turn-based world map and, well, I already told you what I think of that.

Total Warhammer Is a dream cross over for me, It's something I and many other people have wished would happen ever since we played some of the earlier Total War games, there was even a Warhammer mod at one point.  I have dumped a crazy amount of hours into this game already and got my moneys worth. This game Is enjoyable, CA have done a really good job of bringing to life units from tabletop (TT from now on If I need to type it again) both with sticking to the lore and just the art style. Armies feel quite diverse (more so if you compare this game to games like Shogun 2)  CA have also tried to be more transparant after Rome 2, which even after much hard work still doesnt resemble anything close to the trailer we were shown. So has CA done a good job this time, or sold us another lie?  Honestly for me It's a mixed bag. I really enjoyed my first play throughs with most factions (though maybe not Chaos, I can't quite put my finger on what felt wrong with their playstyle, but even the controversial DLC Beastmen seemed to of nailed the horde gameplay mechanics better than the Chaos Warriors faction)  But.. and there is a few buts. The actual combat Is over way too fast If you play with quite small unit sizes. I honestly take more time getting to the enemy than I do In combat, and units seemed to break too quickly for me to implement intresting tactics like flank charges.  So turn unit sizes up right? Well no, you do this and magic suddenly becomes so very weak It's almost useless. I chased CA for weeks over this issues as It's something they have previously refused to adress, I finally got an answer over Facebook and they just told me It was a complex problem and don't expect It to be fixed soon. The problem Is It's not just magic, unique units like Luminark suddenly go from taking 3 shots to kill say a giant on low unit size, up to 7 shots to kill the same unit on Ultra unit size.  This has really bugged me, magic Is so integral to the tactics and lore of Warhammer, so now you have to pick between low unit sized battles with magic working as intended, but then battles are almost arcade like with how quickly they end. Or gimp magic and other things if you turn unit size up which anyone with a half decent GPU will probably want to do. Sadly I'm now looking to mods to fix this as I remember older Total War games having similar problems so I don't have much faith In CA to fix it anyime soon. That Is a plus for this game though, the ability to mod and a brownie point for CA for making it happen.  Another issue Is how things play out on the actual campaign map. The AI knows exactly how far you can move, and will exploit this (or be clever depending on how you view such artifical difficulty) by attacking your weak settlements, then retreating to a well defended castle. This would be fine now and again but It becomes the only tactic the AI does, leading to benny hill esque chases and whack a mole like gameplay. It also leads to a lack of full on field battles which seems a bit silly for a game with a title like this one has. You can learn to adapt to this, using the ambush stance and baiting, but still, it would be nice if the AI mixed it up more.  Speaking of castles, they have changed sieges from how they have been done In previous games. Now you can only ever attack one corner or sometimes one wall, unlike say Shogun 2 you could attack from all four sides of the castle, then within the castle itself had multiple areas defenders could fall back to. Total Warhammer has dumbed this down with CA's explanation being that the Ai got too derpy In complex sieges. Honestly I think this was a horrible decision and once you have played a siege or two, you have played them all. This really should be a sign for CA that they need to invest In the Ai or even make a new engine. Also In my 200+ hours of playing the Ai has encirlced many of my Castles, but it has never once actually tried to lay sige instead hoping it can starve me out, which I have easily avoided by being able to bring an army along to block it. I'm not sure if that is a bug or again just bad AI.  Speaking of Castles and towns, gone are the village battles, instead you get a field battle with your garrison now which Is another feature I miss. There is no depth to buildings either, In previous games you could tailor cities to do quite unique things, like be a economic power house, or gives troops raised there moral boost. But In this game you will find yourself building the same way over and over again with only a slight variance depending on what military units you wish to produce.  This game is fun, nothing quite beats the moments you swoop down with your Lord on some epic mount and clash with the opposing lord. They have expanded on the religion mechanic from previous games, and now factions like Chaos and Vampire Counts taint the actual map which Is another threat you have to contend with. I do like features like this and I do think CA have done a great job with touches like this which bring the Warahmmer world to life (Or death if you play Vampire Counts :P )  I'm figuring most die hard Warhammer and Total War fans have this now or at least know if It's for them or not. So this review is for people maybe on the fence. And sadly right now I would say avoid. While there is fun to be had here, there are too many broken mechanics or buggy mechanics. I do think this game has the potential for greatness, but CA seem more intrested in pumping out more DLC while ignoring broken things In the main game they sold us. I'm not even opposed to DLC, I think this game could really come into It's own once expanded with more factions and land mass. It's just a slap In the face to customers when they can create entirely new lores of magic, but leave the actual magic system broken for anyone who doesnt want to play with small unit size. The problem with the DLC is the price is pumped up and justified on things like mini cmapaigns which In reality are just zoomed In locked down portions on the map from the grand Campaign, stripped down and sold to us again.  Sadly I have to say give this a miss at the moment until fundamental pillars of the games like magic are worked on and the game is fleshed out more or you can bag it with all of the DLC In some sort of sale.

Okay so firstly I`ve been a fan of the total war series since the original Shogun so I`ve had a fair amount of experience with the series and enjoyed most of the games. If I were to rank them in order of best to worst, Total War: Warhammer would probably be in the lower end of the table. Not to say it isnt a good game by all mean it is. There are however some issues I personally have with it others may disagree however with what I`m about to say but this is what I feel is wrong with the game -   1) Okay so firstly I`ll start off with DLC which a lot of poeple have isssues with too. Namely the pricing and the content of said DLC. So the prices are for the DLC are pretty damn high for what they are and personally I`d reccomend waiting for a sale before purchasing them. However this isnt my main problem with the DLC`s, no that belongs to the content of the DLC`s. You start off with only 4 playable factions (However I should note that they all feel unique to play and have their own styles of play) which for me is poor for a £40 game. You can play either the orks, empire, dwarfs or the vampire counts which is nice, but you cant play as chaos without buying them and to mean that is just bs. The game essentially revolves around preparing for a massive invasion by chaos which in my opionin makes them one of the most important factions if not the most important faction in the game, but you have to buy them (I know right, the ♥♥♥♥ CA?) oh and if you want blood and gore graphic you gotta pay to unlock that too. Thats all I say on DLC hopefully you got my point.  2)Are the units balanced? Simple answer no, no they`re not. However there are mods to help with this (yay for modders much love guys and gals) so until CA sort their ♥♥♥♥ mods will help. And due to this balancing issue I feel as though it takes away from the tactical options players can employ for example to beat a stronger army if yours is slightl;y weaker.   3) Is the ai still dumb as inbred rock? eh pretty much, and I`ll give you an example I was playing the vampire counts againts the empire and within my army I had a vahgulf (i think thats how its spelled, not sure i called it cuddles) now my vargulf was getting pretty low fighting some reiksgaurd cavalry so I pulled cuddles back, instead of chasing down and killing cuddles the ai instead decided to charge its cav into my spear units allowing cuddles to regen all his health and then proceed to violently slap the enemy to death once back in the fight. This ai error secured a win for me from an uncertain battle. However again there are mods that can help with this (modders 2 - 0 CA)   4) I`m not sure how others feel on this but I think the campaign map is too small, all though that is just my opionin and theres not much else to say on that.   5) This game also misses out a lot of content from Warhammer lore, most notibly for me are the factions that are completely missing from this game, which for me take away from the whole experience I`ll list quiclky; Elves, Dark Elves, Skaven, Chaos Dwarfs, Tomb Kings, and the various cult of chaos (there may be more but thats what I can remember).   However despite these shortcomming the game overall is still pretty good, a cash cow but at least not a bad one. It is still a fun a game with a lot of cool new features e.g. after capturing a settlement it will have certain features that relate to your faction. I would reccomend this game but not for the current price, especially with the DLC`s. I would rate this game 6/10 without mods and a 7/10 with, which is a shame because it could have been great but greed seems to have infested CA within the past few games. As far as the game itself is concerned, it's an amazing game if you are a fan of the Warhammer universe, and an alright game if you are a Total War fan. It's missing some key elements from previous Total War titles that made them feel more fleshed out, such as larger building trees and better economic/social mechanics, but overall those are elements that you can learn to live without and hope they bring in the future.  With all of that being said though, if you can, hold off on buying ANY of the DLC for this game (Or even the game itself if you are hesitant), because it is absolutely ridiculous what Creative Assembly is doing (It's just a continuation of what we've allowed them to do in previous Total War titles). $3 for blood textures that should already have been included as a free download for the countries allowed to have blood textures?! $8 for a playable faction that is ALREADY in the game and should have been included from day 1?! Now 18 DOLLARS for ONE race, with many more still unaccounted for, meaning CA may very well try to do that for every single one?! I understand DLC, hell I work and play in the game industry, but that is not a conductive DLC strategy to keep fans. There is a reason why CD Projekt RED and Witcher 3 is so beloved with its DLC strategy, because they understood what should have been included, what should be free downloads, and what should be paid for. I would gladly pay for a $29.99 expansion that brought us around 4 new races and a new expansion to the main campaign map... but nearly $20 for a single faction that's a horde race that will not add anything to the campaign map, besides a 'mini-campaign' that's not a part of the main campaign, how is that justified?  Fans are fed up, and by the looks of these reviews, it's about to reach it's boiling point.

Do I recommend it? No. It's boring.  After a fair amount of time playing this game as the Vampire Counts in the campaign, I got bored (around 50 turns in). As the Vampires, you're really only up against the Empire provinces for most of the game as Dwarfs and Chaos ignore you, Orcs won't do anything until way into the game, and Bretonnia is a joke. And I mean... you can only conquer a certain few settlements meaning conquest is limited pretty much just to humans which are very straight-forward, pretty much the same low-level armies all the freaking time.  When you get down to it, Total War: Warhammer lacks the variety that the Warhammer series has. Even with Chaos as a playable faction (now what, $8?) - it's still lacking because most units are just the same units with different weapons. I was so disappointed to find that half of the entire unit selection was just Grave Guard - Grave Guard (with great weapons) or Quarrelers - Quarrelers (with great weapons.   And I don't think I'm saying enough about the campaign. BORING AS HELL! And when you get into the parts where all Chaos declare war on you, it's just annoying to be honest because you can't kill them, and if you conquer all the way up to the Chaos wastes, you just leave an army or two to fight them every few turns, and before long, near the end of the game, you're really only playing with two armies tops because the rest are sitting in one place, reading for the bland and unending army of Chaos or their tribes to come hit you, or the Greenskins down in the south because the Dwarfs pretty much always can't beat them. And then what? Boom, public order problems across the board, so you just camp for twenty turns or so, and then maybe, just maybe the Dwarfs want to fight, and you have to go pull off an army to come clean up the mess. I mean, that's all it is, really, like cleaning up a room for spring cleaning. It's tiresome.  I've played Total War since Medieval, and I was so excited for this. I was unsure at first because of the BS that's always pulled, but then I saw some videos and my mind was made up because I thought the variety you see in some multiplayer videos are what you'll see in the campaign. Oh how naive I was to think Total War: Warhammer wasn't going to be a problem.  The worst thing is, this isn't something you can really fix. The campaign was screwed from the start, and even with new playable factions and greater variety in units, it will be just plainly not fun to play.  Kudos to producing a game that works at launch though. I can't believe I'm actually relieved with the fact that the product I bought wasn't unplayable. I'm so tired of being dissatisfied in Total War. I don't know what went wrong with you guys, but knock this ♥♥♥♥ off. I'm not buying any DLCs, and I'm going to wait at least a month before I think about buying whatever new game you put out.

Overall, this is one of the worst Total War games I have every wasted $60 on.

I've been playing the TW series since their very first Shogun: TW game. Obviously it's not owned by the same company any more but I own every game in the series thus far. Warhammer is a completely different concept than normal TW games as it's fantasy and not loosely historical in gameplay. The base game is pretty decent, albeit missing a lot of mechanics of previous titles. Good mechanics improvements like cavalry and archer/gun units, they seem more viable to use in my armies in this game than the last. The map is large enough and has its own quirks in gameplay to make it so you can't be all powerful and roll over everyone early on.  Here is the problem with this game as compared to previous titles. The base mechanics are nearly identical to Atilla, and the gameplay is run essentially the same with the hordes. It seems like they reskinned the entire game to be Warhammer themed and shrunk the map to half or less than half of their previous title. It's a fantasy title with magic, monsters, flight......yet i feel like i'm playing a 60$ small DLC based off of Atilla. I wish they had made all sorts of new things gameplay wise but it's just build several basic buildings to unlock a few units and try to conquer your neighbor. There are extremely limited amounts of unique units, everyone has essentially the same types of units just reskinned with added/subtracted stats and amount of soldiers. This is a trend that has plagued the TW series for the last several releases where they just toss the same types of soldiers with different skins and stats for each faction. This makes the game pretty dull as soon as you get a few hours in since there's no diversity between any faction.  Currently 6 factions are available for gameplay, IF you bought the DLC for 2 of the factions. I remember years ago buying a base game that needed no patches for bug fixes and it also came with 10-20 unlockable factions. The current state of this series is DLC based for not a cheap price. I can understand maybe a dollar or two for new factions/mechanics but not nearly 20$ for a reskinned chaos faction with attributes from dwarfs/orcs. This is a quick way to get your loyal fanbase that buy every release ever to leave and never return. I am capable of spending 20$ more on a DLC but i refuse if it's a half-cocked release that only breathes the desperation for more income.   Take the current secondary and maybe even tertiary factions and make them more unique, make them free to play with unlocks through gameplay. Currently the only way i can enjoy this game is by loading it with mods from the workshop that add better scaling, mechanics and soldier types for each faction. The only way i can recommend this game is if the purchaser loads it with mods to make it closer to a completed game, and even then they're limited on other factions unless they dish out more cash.  I used to get thousands of hours of gameplay out of a base game, expansions not included and without mods with TW's older releases. Now i'll be lucky to get 500 out of this game unless i want to spend well over 100$ on this game plus DLC content that should have been included in the base purchase. The state of the game for me is currently play to mid to late game and get bored with it and change factions. And this is with it heavily modded, when it was the vanilla version i lost interest within a couple hours. Buy at your own risk and understand you'll have to be dishing out more and more money to play this game that should have released completed for 60$.
I love this game but it is far too pricey for what it gives you when you consider the DLC practices. Buy this game when all the DLCs for this game are here at a sale.

So let's work out what this game is.  It's a faily standard Total War game. The building, army recruitement, agents should all be very familiar if you played any previous TW game. The obvious biggest difference is the fantasy setting of course, with magic, giant monsters, and OP heroes. It most certainly adds variety to earlier games with very similar swordsmen/spearmen etc. Factions feel different, and play different. The look and animations of the units is stunning. Another good point is that there are no useless 'peasant' units. Lower tier troops are weaker, but far from useless.  Now to the bad parts: 1. Battles are very short. Most battles are over in less than 5 mins. Even sieges take no more than 15 mins. It's annoyng as you cn't enjoy the main part of the game, unless you watch a replay in slow motion. To add to that, the lords and heroes and some units have abilities you need to activate manually every 30-60 sec, so the battle becomes a clickfest. 2. Campaign is short. You are really rushed in the campaign to deal with the plot driven big threat. It could be the great apocalyptic battle, but it just isn't. 3. Army movement. The AI in campaign is perfectly aware of your movement, including various modifiers, so loves to have his army just millimeters away from your max movement. and then force march away the next turn. It also seems to have a lot of free movement when retreating. Chasing raider armies typically involves at least 2 of yours to one of theirs and gets very frustrating. 4. Cities. Minor towns don't exist on the map. The battles take place on an open field. No, I am not joking. Also the default garrison of the town in 6 basic squads, so it's almost the same as being completely undefended. Armies are limited, so you cannot have a defence army in small towns. The only choice is the 'optional' defence building, which does add walls and more garrison to fully upgraded minor towns. This limits your town to merely 2 useful building slots.  5. Sieges. The sieges themselves are a massive letdown. You don't assault cities. You assault a short straight section (or corner) of wall with few houses behind it. Doesn't matter if it's human, ork, dwarf, it's all the same, only the look of the walls changes, the layout is the same couple of presets. It would have been somewhat unterstandable if it was some first stage of a multi-stage assault, but it's not. 6. DLC. I left this one to the last, because it's not my main problem with the game. It is still a problem though. 7 months after release the game has more DLC than the game cost at release. I really cannot see how this can be justified. The DLC does not add up to a new game, not even close. From the pre-release cutting contnent from the finished game (Chaos faction), to making elite easily recruitable units DLC (Regiments of Renown), this game is going in the wrong direction.  I really want to recommend this game, but not in the current state. Buy it in a bundle on sale when the full game is released.

Is this a good game on its own? If you like Warhammer or fantasy yes, you will probably have fun with it. However if you are like me and have owned and played every total war game previous to this then you will probably be disappointed. In short, good Warhammer game, bad total war game. My main issues are:  Town battles exist only once you have built walls. You cannot fight in a town without walls it will just throw you into a field battle Animations are either lazy or non existant. There are no reloading animations for ranged units, there are no one on one fights or death animations, a unit of black orcs will just swing their weapons around randomly and sometimes an enemy will collapse dead, projectiles don't actually strike the enemy or their shields like in all the other total war games. Siege battles are super simplified. They take place on only a single angle or sometimes an L shape, the enemy starts in range of your towers no matter what, every unit besides cavalry and monsters can climb the walls because they all teleport ladders into existance when they read the walls. The epic cinematic experience of sieges is gone with this iteration of the total war franchise. And I know I already mentioned the pocket ladders, but they really are terrible.  Town managment is very simplified, you dont really need to make trade offs or decisions about what you want to build in 99% of your cities, the best thing to build is the same as every other town.   It feels like this game has potential but needs a lot more polish. It could have used another six months in development. Hopefully they'll be updating it consistently and soon with more than just DLC.

Being a huge fan of both Total War series (played every game since Medieval, Medieval II being favorite) and Warhammer universe (collected Bretonnia since 2007), I really have waited for this one. The first thing I didn't like was, of course, first-day-DLC with second most popular army in FB. The whole DLC thing is a plague slowly killing TW series - while in Empire or Napoleon DLC really just added more units with medium-high usefulness in game, in Shogun 2 there were  no differences between factions initially  - you had to buy DLC with faction-unique units, which is utterly ridiculous. In Rome 2 the greed of publishers reached new heights - now whole factions had to be bought (no, I do not count clans from Shogun 2 as factions), and this continues in Warhammer. C'mon,Sega, that's not funny, I have already bought your game, and it cost as any AAA-title with DLC worthy of free-to-play. So let's be fair, DLCs are the main reason I'm making a bad review, but the game itself is not that bad not to be worthy of purchase with 60% off  PROS: -It's Total War -It's Warhammer -Every faction feels unique, with different playstyles and gimmicks -New types of units, monsters and flying cavalary/beasts/whatever -The graphics are reasonably good -Siege battles look cool and are pretty desperate. One direction is ok, IMHO, with only case it blows is when defender receives reinforcements -Chaos looks badass. Same for Vampire Counts -Single player is more or less balanced -Stupid abilities like 'press X to fight harder for 30 seconds' aka 'use the whip' from Rome II are removed -Magick! And it's actually balanced! (unlike tabletop, where those damn High Elves will burn you to oblivion while hiding under the banner of the World Dragon, ugh, damn you, Matt Ward...) -CA fixed some diplomacy issues but... CONS: -Diplomacy is redundant except 'Join confederation' option. Allies NEVER help for real. Sure, they declare war on your enemies but their armies are wandering somewhere minding their own business instead of marching straight into the fray (make your own WWII joke here) -Combat is very fast -No town battles  -The map is not as accurate as it could be. For example, Moot's location is wrong -AI is still ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, but it's an improvement over dreaded Rome II and Attila - Beautiful   swordplay from Shogun 2 is replaced by err... well, something worse than animations from Medieval II -Chaos invasion looks iffy - it doesn't feel like THE End Times -Playing Chaos feels iffy - you're not an unstoppable force but a bunch of beggar nomads -Strategic part lacks compexity, especially in city managment -Some things feel rushed - why banners can be given to any unit (how CA imagines Varghulf carrying a banner)? Why there is no representation for them in real-time battles (same question for magick items)?  -Stupid province system straight out of Rome II. Damn it, I liked Medieval II system so much more -No Bretonnia in singleplayer outside of mods, and they still suck in multiplayer :(

Their units have an artificial morale, units don't route but instead they disappear 'disintegrate' in battle. They just changed the looks and name but for practical purposes every faction plays the same.    Technical issues: -Nvidia users will face horrible stuttering, even if you get decent frames per second the units stutter like doing a robotic dance. Maybe they will introduce the missing features with DLC, I hope they do somehting like the Augustus FREE DLC in Rome 2 where they revamped everything wrong but right now as it is, the launch is on par or maybe worse than Rome 2 launch.   Don't bee fooled by warhammer fanboys, they praise this game because it's the only decent warhammer game they've ever had.  I would rather recommend you to go play Rome 2, Attila or Shogun 2. Those 3 games are superior to this one in every aspect. Only buy if you're fan of warhammer or prefer a fantasy setting to a real one.

Tl;Dr - If you're looking for a quick fix for your Total War itch, don't bother here. If you really dig the fantasy setting or already own the previous Total War installments, get Warhammer at a 50% discount minimum. This should have been an expansion back for Attila (price point-wise).  I know I'll get a lot of flack for not liking this iteration of Warhammer come to life in an RTS game, but frankly, it's not the idea of Warhammer I don't like, it's the implementation. Essentially I was pleasantly surprised to see CA go after the Warhammer franchise. A franchise that combines fantasy and the joy of medieval combat sounds like a dream come true, right? Unfortunately, the result is far from the truth.  Quite frankly, this game is a dissapointment on so many levels for me. While you can still get enjoyment out of it, especially if you are a hardcore Warhammer fan, that does not make up for the sheer lack of overall effort that shows everytime you boot a game up. But enough of that, let's get started with the usual list!  Pros:  1. The graphics - The game looks good...I mean...REALLY good. It has plenty of visual flair and charm despite my growing distate for the game as a whole.  2. Leaders - For the most part each leader adds a new and interesting mechanic to your battles, a nice change of pace from the political setups from Rome 2 and Attila.  3. Siege and Regular Battles - Regular battles have different visual styles that vary based on location, whilst sieges can certainly look gorgeous they also have MAJOR cons that we'll get to shortly.  4. No Politics/children - This one just speaks for itself.  And now, the Cons:  1. Complete lack of quanitity - So, remember when I made the jab at Atilla with 'Attila Lite' in my last review? Yeah, Warhammer is even worse, which you would almost think to be impossible. Now I get that there are only so many races, but dear gods, one faction per race? Seriously? And people try to justify that? Basically if you want to play coop with someone you cannot be the same race despite there being multiple factions per race. You also cannot play a different faction after you've grown tired of playing the exact same starting position with the exact same enemies around you. And no, different lords do not add enough variety to change that.  2. Great Power Debuff - This one just speaks for itself.  3. Agents - It was a pretty cool idea to have 'heroes' that you can use to bolster your army, such as using a Dwarven Engineer to increase the stats and reload speed of your artillery. Each hero has unique abilities for each race and you could really benefit from them in battle....oh...you say that the AI will only use them like agents from the previous Total War games and eventually you'll be dealing with the six or so agents from all your enemies that are completely unstoppable just like Attila? Well that was a waste of time.  4. Enemy Units Routing...Psych! - Yeah, this is probably the worst and most unrealistic part of Warhammer, a univese with gryphons (griffons?) and dragons. Picture this, you're in a close battle with the enemy lord, your troops have flanked his best warriors and you've decimated the enemy archers and horseman. Now all that's left is to bring this battle to a clo-....wait....why are my Hammerers dropping like flies? *glance around map for hidden units* Why the hell is that archer unit of only 10-20 men back in battle? ♥♥♥♥♥! How did that horseman unit of 15 come back and flank my warriors?! Yeah, get ready for this constantly happening. It's annoying and drags out battles for far too long. You'll constantly find weak units coming back. My advice? Don't even bother playing the dwarves if that annoys you. The Slayers are the only thing you'll have that can run down those units to make sure they don't come back.  5. Settlements/Cities - Wow do these look half-♥♥♥♥♥, just from the in-game ui alone. Do you remember Yu-Gi-Oh? How about Pegusus' Toon world? Yeah. That's pretty much what every city looks like from the grand campaign...toon towns.  6. Siege Battles - And now for the largest let down of all. I'm sure you've already heard of this, but siege battles suck. About 1/4 of the city is available to you, limiting your encirclment options to a head-on charge, Units pull ladders out of their hidden bags of holding, lodged somewhere securely in their rears, and when you get on the enemy walls? Yeah, your units get down by clipping through the battlements...Such a showcase of effort and time right there. But the worst part? The cities actually look really good, especially the background art. All of which just makes you wish for an actual siege battle like the previous games.  7. Siege Battles Continued - Settlements don't have siege battles unless you've builts walls. What does that mean? It means no more using choke points to your advantage on low level settlements, instead you get to fight on a generic battle map. I guess those budget cuts even hit your engineers.  At the end of the day, the best I can say about Warhammer is that it looks pretty. That it has potential. But sadly there's very little effort and quality here, especially when compared to previous Total War entries (Attila included). The lack of faction choices within each race is a sour taste every time you start a new game, especially so if you plan to play coop. Creatively, Warhammer is a step in the right direction for CA, but from a mechanic and quality standpoint it's miles behind Shogun 2.  9/25 Edit - Spell check
