I have played this game for hours and hours. The only reason why I played this for so long was the Modding community. The Vanilla game is a pathetic attempt at a Total War Game. You received very few unit choices, unable to conquer the whole world and were limited on many other choices.   Now, let's talk Total War games. How many folks remember how awesome controlling infantry lines in Empire or Napoleon were? How about when you were able to control an alleyway in a city using your Phalanx's spear formation ability or a Pike wall? All those unit abilities and means to wheel right or wheel left with your units are gone. Now all units have innate abilities. Do you want to chose between fire arrow, heavy shot, whistling arrow or standard shot? That’s gone. Now they just shoot. Catapult want to shoot explosive, scatter or acid shots? Nope. Just set it up and forget about it. There is no micromanagement needed. All those cool units you made for specific battles or enemies are gone.   You can no longer fight in your small city should the AI attack. The battles are now in a field near no houses and no way to use the city to your advantage when attacked. So your garrison forces abandoned the town, rode out into a nice field for the enemy to slaughter there. Why was this removed? I loved the struggle of trying to save my city and not start it on fire in the process or I had to pay for the damage of defending in the city. Garrison forces are also not identified as Garrison should you have another army there. I used to give the Garrison units to my Co-op friend as they were expendable. He could lose all the troops and they came back automatically in the city. Terrible.   The AI will only attack you if they overwhelmingly will win a battle. Otherwise they will hide just out of your army movement range and never fight you. You can spend upwards of 10 turns chasing an army before you somehow manage to trap them using another army/armies or agents. It is really annoying. They will also only attack your city if it is 4000 vs 1 old drunk guy with a rusty spear. Which seems good in a sense, but there are very few battles I’ve found myself playing out because I either outnumber or they outnumber. It is rare to have a 1v1 fight that is even and requires my skills to win.   Want a navy? Nope...you get transport boats. The awesome naval combat of Empire and Shogun 2 (Fall of the Samurai) are gone. You can build ports, but they are just for economy. I don't understand the economy at all. One turn I am making 3000 and the next I am making 90 bucks.   Food is removed. No longer can you destroy crops to starve an opponent.   Heroes seems awesome on paper...then you fight a Chaos lord who is surrounded by 6 units of Dwarves with axes and winning….soundly. It will look like a mosh pit as the lord eventually pushes his way through the 2000 angry Dwarves and outruns everything on the battlefield to escape to fight another day. I’ve had many of battles that were critical to win against Chaos and once I trapped the lord, I had all units attack, I hit Triple Speed on the Battle Control and walked off to get a beer.   Where were the Elves? This is the first Fantasy game in history with no Elves...of any kind. Why no Bretonians? They are a hilarious faction.   Agents could be fun...I suppose. Granted, the AI will level up their Agent and then cause death and dismemberment every turn. Unless you have an equally awesome Agent, you won’t be able to kill them to you do. Want to convert or delay the agent? You can’t. It is kill only.   Diplomacy. Remember in Medieval Total War where you had to send a physical diplomat to an enemy territory? Not here. Every. Single. Turn. People will ask you to join a war against someone you might not be ready to fight. In Medieval I could KILL THE MESSENGER and my diplomacy screen would be blissfully quiet for awhile. It would hurt my diplomacy for a bit with that particular faction, but it sent a message.   Speaking of diplomacy. Remember how you could Gift Cities or Demand cities in Diplomacy? Nope. You can Declare war, peace, trade and that is about it. Want to marry a daughter off? What daughters? Want to send a son as hostage to secure peace. What sons? Just sling money around if you want peace/war.   Orks are warlike and have to be fighting or they take attrition. Or you can click the SUBDUE button and they are immediately fine again. Pointless.   Magic. This sounds awesome! Your Necromancer will be able to cast 1-2 spells and then he is out of magic. He spends the rest of the fight picking at his fingernails. Some mages were so useless after 2 spells I stopped making them. Now...the Amber Wizard is awesome!   Heroes. In the past hero units didn’t fight with you. They added bonuses to your army/city instead. Well, you can’t put a Priest in a city to convert them to your religion any more. You can’t force a rebellion. All Heroes really do are DIE. If you get a Fire Mage on a horse and then do Autoresolve in a battle you will notice your Fire Mage died and no one else took damage. Autorresolve will have your precious Fire Mage immediately charge HEADFIRST into combat and die. Constantly...never give a mage a horse. Ever. Unless you control every battle. I’ve had to remove my Mage from fights before as they had 24HP left after the last fight, but everyone else was at 100%.   All in all...this game removed so much from Total War games that I loved and added very little to write home about. I hope there are some serious updates coming or I am hoping there is a new Design team for the next Total War to bring back the tactical wargame I loved.

I haven't played Total War games before and when i heard about the Warhammer based game i desided to give it a try. Unfortunately the game is built around experienced players only.   The tutorial contains 2 videos that explain how the controlls work in the battle, nothing about how you actually should use your units. The in game tutorial is a very easy battle that you really don't have to do anything to win. while in game you suddenly discover heroes that cannot be killed by regular armies but can assasinate your general or block your path every turn making your life miserable. nothing of this even mentioned in the 'tutorial'. not to mention the computer almost always manages to get almost 2 times as much soldiers as i have at the location despite me having max army cap on the hero and all that on 'normal' difficulty. if you are new to this series prepare to dig into the guides and streams or youtube videos becose thats how you learn to play this game, really dissapointing...  Edit: after some learning(?!): 1) the game feels very linear in the research trees and building trees. very little meaningfull choise to make there and some technologies are just overal better than the alternatives. 2) one resource economy, rare resources are available but depending on your race you may not have any allies to trade them with at all. you can manage economy by just building a few income buildings in your provinces and not recruiting unneeded armies. very simple. 3) agents - the game is about agents not armies, they can assasinate enemy heroes and leader, kill their armies, prevent them from moving, and all that without even declaring war on them. to top it out they can only be killed by other agents so you must have leveled agents or when the computer brings his agents you will be helpless against them. watching how they murder your army.  verdict, very weak and boring for strategy lovers. if you are looking for a nice strategy to force you to think and customize your empire keep looking nothing for you here. if you like the series, warhammer lore and or simplified strategies you might want to check this out.

Because ♥♥♥♥ this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ DLC policy, 20 dollars for a whole faction? Really? That's a third of a ♥♥♥♥ing game. Or a really good game from 3 years ago. Price gouging a basic faction and restricting it behind a paywall (pay to play Chaos, the main antagonists? ♥♥♥♥ off). And now they are telling us that we should pay the same price for Chaos, a whole ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ faction that should be there to begin with, to unlock a handful of Lords and a unit pack, which would be a couple bucks in any other Total War title. Since this is a Game's Workshop liscence (a company notorious for price hiking the ♥♥♥♥ out of their customer base, and one of the reasons my relationship with Warhammer is strictly through media), I highly suspect they are behind this.   So let's break it down:   The DLC policy: It should be made clear that this game isn't BAD per se, just unfinished, intentionally. This downvote is to protest this product and to recommend that any who didn't get this game as part of a free package (like I did) wait for it to be dropped in price, vote with your money, vote a lot less than they are asking.    Negatives: 1. Again, Chaos 2. Beastmen, holy ♥♥♥♥ Beastmen. A subpar campaign that looked like it took a collective afternoon to put together, units that are ripped straight from chaos. I understand the modeling requirements and whatnot, but with this games animation quality as compared to other total wars (more on that later), there is simply no justification for this much money. This would have been an excellent 8 to 10 dollar edition. Anything more is pushing it. Don't buy this, please, you are just asking for them to assrape your wallet in the future. 3. The upcoming Grim and the Grave expansion, its a unit pack, we'll get 2 legendary lords, a couple types, and 5 new units, only two of which will have anything unique about their models other than some particle effects. Other than that we have units that are simply stat and ability changes along with MAYBE a retexture, again, wait for half off to stomach this.   Positive: 1. I mean, they gave us Bretonnia, which is nice, I guess. It's a bit of a hollow faction, I guess it was a little too much to hope they would make them more unique after they were squatted for Age of Smegmar. 2. Blood for the Blood God, I'm giving the DLC a lot of ♥♥♥♥, but I'm not unreasonable, this is company standard and its not really that bad. It's more of a marketing tactic to save it from an M rating.   The Game:   Negatives: 1. A lot of the UI functionality has been dumbed down or eliminated from better Total War's like Shogun 2. State Management isn't as complex as it used to be, which I guess would be a positive for some, but I like Grand Strategy and things like Heart's of Iron, so micromanging my state and economy is my thing. 3. Diplomacy is still hilariously barebones, which is sorta fitting I guess, now that I think about it, but still, make this better. 4. The animation, frankly the animations in this game suck ♥♥♥ compared to the badass fight sequences of the modern Total War's. There is no unique anything, and it feels like each unit has maybe 5 attack animations for everything. So no Grave Guard vs Imperial Halberdiers with special mapping out and counters like other total wars, nor anything to indicate this is anything other than them swinging wildly. Honestly if this issue was fixed I could see justification behind the steep pricing in the factions. But otherwise, this is Rome 1 level of basic animation, and for all that this game asks, its an unforgivable absence. 5. Lack of key factions. Where in ♥♥♥♥s name are the Elves? Locked behind a 25 dollar paywall I bet. Lizardmen, Tomb Kings proper (which better not be a high price because they'll just be an extention of the Vampire Count's unit stacks), and Skaven. This is a negative because they'll be introduced at a ♥♥♥♥ton of money per faction more than likely, I'll edit this out if this proves false. 6. In my opinion the new siege weapon building kinda sucks, I wanna tow my own gear around damnit! Minor complaint.   Positives: 1. The unit variety is ♥♥♥♥ing outstanding, easily the most colorful variety of any Total War. 2. The AI is a lot better than most Total War's, and in combat I think the enemy even uses basic tactics now. 3. The unique character and characteres within each faction are awesome. I love how the Orc AI kinda just zergs in no matter the Odd's and how the Count's have endless horde's of expendable terror troops. The corruption system is a nice touch too. 4. Hero's are ton's of fun and a great addition. It also kind of lends you a badass with ton's of cool abilities to rally your people behind, much more fun than the calvalry on crack that was the generals of old. 5. Surprisingly balanced, coin per coin, which is good because everything Warhammer has struggled with this in the past (Fish of Fury, Necrons anyone?). 6. Even if a little bare, the questing system is fun and add's a much needed feeling of things being personal in your sprawling super Empire.   Overall I enjoyed this game, however I cannot spare it a thumbs up, in small part because of the negatives, but in much larger part because of the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t DLC practices. Cut this ♥♥♥♥ out.   Though this has gotten me wondering if we could get a working Warhammer 40k Total War, what with the mass attritional warfare being par for the course in that universe I don't think there would be as many problems as a modern era total war would face. Though there would be some huge ♥♥♥ technical hurdles, it would be much more doable.

There are two main criteria this game should be judged on: being a TW game and being a Warhammer game. It fails both miserably (and the fact that there's so many good reviews out there only indicates and disheartening drop in standards in the game industry).  As a Total War game:  - Diplomacy is almost totally useless. The AI is even more random than previous game in the series, declaring war on supposed allies for no good reason while actual bad guys are rampaging all over the map. Meanwhile members of your own race (whom you'd expect to have a bonus with) won't even agree to a non-aggression pact, often enough.  - Town development is bland. Gone are the days of towns having an actual population (Medieval II, how I miss thee) and the varying level of development beign visible on the map. As a friend pointed out: you build farms in the beginning to spur population growth and when all the buildings are upgraded, you demolish all the farms because people don't need food anymore, do they?  - Tech tree has become bloated with useless minor upgrades that don't really do much. This has been a trend for a couple of games now, but with WTW it seems to have reached a new high in uselessness.  - Too many factions are COMPLETE copy & paste jobs, without even the decency of having different skins with different colours on them. There's nothing mroe fun than watching an epic battle of white & red empire troops fighting other white & red empire troops.   - Sieges have reached an all-new low, with ridiculous insanities like mounted knights destroying castle gates by poking them with their lances; siege towers moving on their own vollition, while full of troops, to the enemy wall; enemies routign through solid walls; your own soldiers pullign ladders out of their pockets to scale the wals; your own troops subsequently refusing to come down said ladders when you order them to retreat; last but not least, you no longer besiege a city, you besiege a tiny corner of it. Epic, is it not?  - battlefields are even more bland than ever. Not a farmstead in sight, all you ever see are either forests and mountains or, well, just mountains. Occasionally some random ork effigy will show up, even if there are no orks around and you're just invading Kislev with chaos warriors.  - the animations are all the same. For everyone. All the time. Zooming in becomes pointless after a few fights. Not to mention some units don't even have a full set of animations (why aren't my troops reloading, ffs?)  - gone are many other basic optiosn like 'loose order' for troops being peppered by arrows, wedge formation for cavalry (beign unlocked by some tech doesn't count) etc. No idea why they couldn't be arsed to leave these in.  - some units don't even have their own sounds. For instance, the Chaos champion gets new soundbites when he acquires a chaos steed. Soudns that he keeps using once you switch from chaos steed to manticore. Buying some stock lion soundbites and putting them through an editor was too time-consuming, I guess.  - Lord & Hero skill trees also feel totally bland and uninspired. +3 Armour when you already have 60 or 80. Big whoop. It's ridiculously sad if whenever you get a level-up with your character you couldn't care less because you can't be arsed trawling through the optiosn to find one that will actually give you somethign interesting.  - Characters can't lead units and have no bodyguards. In fact, no hero can in any circumstance ever be attached to any unit, ever. They jsut stroll aroudn by their lonesomes. CA compensates for this by givign them ridiculously high HP so they don't die to the first unit they meet. In fact, the complete opposite happens - characters wade through enemies like they'd be fighting toddlers armed with plastic straws.  - Hordes are usually cool. Until you create a fresh one after you already moved with the first one. Then notice the Horde infighting mechanic and how it will cost you almost 25% of your troops just for spawning a new general. GG CA!  - towns withotu walls disappear completely off the battle map. Not like you could use those narrow streets for defensive purposes, could you? Take a hint from the Jon Snow play-book and let the garrison juet run out and meet the advancing army in the open field.  - I could go on but by now I hope you either got my point or you're probably not reading anymore.  As a Warhammer game it initially seems cool and fun. But then after you play for a bit you start notcing many different problems that become worse and worse.  - Warriors of Chaos, the main antagonist, are only playable if you fork over more cash. No, the week 1 gratuity doesn't help. They should come with the basic game.  - Balthasar Gelt, the Supreme Patriarch of the Colleges of Magic, can't be appointed to this office when you start the campaign with him; instead, you can appoint random lords who aren't even wizards. Because who cares about the lore, right?  - If you choose to start the campaign with Ungrim Ironfist, the Slayer King of Karak Kadrin, you are still playing the 'Dwarfs' faction, still starting in Karaz-a-Karak (Thorgrim's capital) and Karak Kadrin won't even give you a non-aggression pact, doing their own thing in the north.  - Kislev is just a copy&paste job of the generic empire race, with the exact same units and the exact same white & red uniforms. Who cares that they're actually a cross between medieval russians, cossacks and poles, with their own style of fighting and their own lore of magic?  - Many other empire provinces, while they'd have different uniforms and focus on various aspects of warfare, are identical copy&paste jobs of the generic empire faction.  - Runesmiths can, in this game, ASSASSINATE enemy characters. If you don't understand why this is stupid, I feel sorry for you. I recommend you grab some warhammer books off the interwebs and delve into the rich lore of this fantasy world. Then weep at the silliness that is WTW.  - There are no Challenge mechanics. By all the gods, even Mark of Chaos had Challenges. Not to mention it had skills designed specifically for challenges.  I'd like to write some nice summation of all these, but this absolute turd of a game is not worth it. CA have completely lost my respect.

Well, I'm not sure what going on, but about 10 turns into every game I've started, I get slaughtered by multiple Orc armies, far bigger than what I've had a chance to build......  And I mean massively bigger. I've not even got my proviences up to level 3 yet and they are sending in full armies. I'd be completely bankrupt with even one army that size.  I literally can't get any fun out of this game at the moment.....  Continued......  Well, managed to get a little further and discovered a wonderful little mechanic of the orcs.... They 'Waaarrgghh' which instead of been something sensible..... instead magically creates an entire second army next to their main army.....  So now Orcs are magical summoning creatures??? Come on this is really pathetic..... Not only is it a terrible mechanic lore-wise... Orcs just don't magically appear in the middle of eneemy territory, but game-play wise its even worse. You have one army which can easily win..... random chance, waarrrgghh happens, you are now outnumbered two to one.   Random roll of the dice decides everything, zero skill at all.   This whole game is just a reskinned Rome 2 with heros added. No real attempt has been made to account for the major universe differences (Orc 'agents' been safe in dwarf territory? Right.... shoot on sight... they can't pretend to be a dwarf but cos its just reskinned rome....)   I am really really disappointed in this game, it seems like Creative labs have really done an EA on us here. Absolutely minimum effort has been put into this to basically reskin Rome 2 into Warhammer. No real effort has been made to actually give the game any depth and so many of the mechanics are just really badly thought out.   Very very disappointed.  Cont 2....  Well I worked out the issue is basically the orc Waarrggh mechanic is so OP in the AI hands, mostly vs the AI itself, so basically the Orcs are massacaring all the southern dwarfs in like the first 5 turns and then having a massive empire + boosted heros to come straight at you with.  A few lucky battles and the orcs become pretty near unstoppable.  Basically most of the problems with this game seem to come down to a poor AI and poor economy. The battles themselves are decent as you'd expect from total war.  Other issues:  Items quests are placed far far too far from your homeland.... I mean literallly the far ends of the map. Not sure how anyone thought 'march your army to the middle of nowhere for 10 turns' was a good mechanic  Chaos 'end days' very underwhelming. I had just overpowered the green skins, managed to wipe out the vampire counts.... my armies start poodling north to be told Chaos has been defeated. I suspect again, an AI problem.  For end days, not even taking out the upper empire proviences is a bad mechanic. Losing cities is far too easy, happens far too quickly and the penalties can be absolutely massive, litereally, back to square 1 in one turn. Defensive garrisons are for the most part useless except at capitals.   The economy/AI is so bad, the combination means, any city that is razed, is never rebuilt. The AI never attempts to rebuild them no matter what so you get dead cities in the middle of empires.... Even at end-game levels, the AI has very few upgraded units/cities.   The 'underpass' mechanic is both completely OP and almost entirely based on a roll of the dice. Get lucky/unlucky and you can basically skip past all enemy defences. If you army can take all comers 1v1, there is no downside really. The fact you can emerge literally anywhere is just too powerful and makes a complete mockery of any kind of defensive armies, you can literally skip straight past them.  The 'uncompletable quests' is annoying as well, why on earth make it so you can't complete a quest because for example that faction has become a vassal of the empire?   The really sad part is, it wouldn't take much to make this into a really good game. Sort the AI out, move a few quests about to be closer to home, fix the economy and the underpass mechanic and you have a really good game.   If they do that in a patch, I'll change my recommendation.

If you are a big fan of Warhammer Fantasy Battles (The tabletop game) this game is a pretty decent portrayal of how to represent the tabletop in real time and the units play pretty true to their plastic counterparts making strategy 'cross-platformed'. The modding community is this game's saving grace, as TW modders are some of the most thorough and dedicated I have seen. This game has a way to go, but with a expansion or two and some good modding- Its a gem.   EDIT 07/21/16- Due to the way CA is piecemealing every piece of content for a 60 USD game, I can no longer recommend it. It was easy to do when the game first came out and CA was saying they were releasing Bretonnia for free- Now its apparent that is the only thing they are 'giving' us and modders have already provided 90% of it to us. Hold off until a sale.

If you want a cool fantasy game with interesting battles, buy this game. If you want a good grand strategy game or the tactical battle depth of TW Shogun 2, buy this on a BIG discount or just stick to Shogun 2, Hearts of Iron 4, Civ 6, or Stellaris.  This game is to 4X and Total War what the new Bud Lites in shiny blue bottles are to beer: a watered down, ♥♥♥♥-poor experience that makes you think you'll love it at first, until you realize there's nothing of substance here. Whatever PM killed the idea of depth in campaign gameplay is full of ♥♥♥♥♥.  Overall, this is a solid single player game for your first 50-100 hours. After that, you either keep fighting the same repetitive AI, or you quickly burn out on the lackluster multiplayer.  Great flavour, fantastic UI. Chaos invasion really improves the pacing of the game, adding much needed challenge in the late game on the higher difficulties.  Graphics could really use some work. They're a definite downgrade since the early trailers of BlackfirePass or the Dwarf Ambush. Textures feel like a moderate upgrade since S2, but animations were far better then due to the matched animation system.  After you finish your first couple campaigns, however, I feel like this game is very lacking. Multiplayer is barebones, without any of the persistent elements (Avatar Mode) that made Shogun 2 so good. Maps are frequently imbalanced and relatively simplistic in their tactical challenges.  Battles are too frenetic and poorly paced, with little to no skirmishing phase and formations are overly simplistic. The sheer breadth of unit types in this game, the incredibly high rate of fatigue buildup, and the specificity of many of their counters forces you to use clumped formations that make reacting to threats easier.  Campaign management is shallow and often lacks meaningful choice. It's incredibly easy to apply the same min-maxed strategy everywhere, and the game doesn't present good reasons not to. Trade and diplomacy lack depth and sensible design. Infrastructure development and economic growth are non-existent, and population growth isn't leveraged in a meaningful way.  I think it says something when your turn-based campaign feels like it has less depth and interesting choice than vanilla Civ 5.  As a final note, I have mixed feelings about the DLC. I only wish they would upgrade existing factions' (generally shallow) campaign gameplay along with updating their unit rosters.  The Grim & the Grave pack is necessary for being competent in MP (which is a total sham), and it doesn't have a new campaign like the King & the Warlord pack despite being the same price.  WE race pack is great, fun mini-campaign (if obviously and obnoxiously scripted) and great to play in battle.  Beastmen DLC is pretty lackluster honestly, and unless you really want the race, don't buy it. It's just another 'Line em up, select all attack move' army in battle, and while the mini-campaign is somewhat interesting, it just doesn't provide a good enough experience to justify the cost. The fact that there's no Boris Todbringer campaign really rubs me wrong.
